updates.update_content:
Dear backers, We wanted to drop you a line to say thank you for your support of Inside Pussy Riot and for being part of making it happen, to update you on the progress of the production and invite you to book tickets to the show which go on sale to the general public today. 
 Please head over to www.insidepussyriot.com for the full details of the show where you can find details of the creative team. We have some very exciting press lined up for the coming weeks and are thrilled to be announcing the cast for the show soon.
For those of you who ordered their tickets during the campaign, we will today post a survey, which will allow you to choose the time and date. Just to remind you you will be able to collect your awesomely designed show book, signed by Nadya, when you come to see the show!

Dear backers, who bought tickets via Kickstarter! Here is to confirm that the tickets have gone on sale, and that we will be in touch with you very shortly to arrange your visit! We would also like to remind you that everyone who ordered their tickets through the campaign will get the show's booklet signed by Nadya, which for everyone else will be on sale before and after the show. Stay tuned!

Our dearest backers, thanks again for your support during the campaign! We are now organising the delivery of your rewards and would like to kindly ask you to help us by answering a few questions in surveys we will be posting soon.
To everyone who ordered their tickets for the show – we'll make a survey a bit later so that you can choose the exact timing that suits you! Bear with us!:)
If you ordered the Ticket + T-shirt package, please choose your T-shirt size (between S and XXL) and let us know in the messages. If you don't respond until September 15th, we'll prepare an L-sized one for you. It will be waiting for you at the venue!

Dear All! 
Thank you immeasurably for your support during our campaign! We are happy to announce that we've reached our funding goal. Despite that, please don't hesitate to support the campaign in its final hour! :) 
We will deliver all your rewards by the end of November (or even earlier in some cases).

There are 11 days to go until the campaign ends and we're so close to our funding goal - we've now raised over £52,000! 
Can you help us get over that final hurdle? We're hoping to exceed our goal if possible, so please, if you haven't done so, pass on the Kickstarter link to your friends, families, colleagues and networks. At this point, every little counts!
Check out some more of our awesome, recent press coverage:

Dear friends, thanks again for your support during the first week of our campaign!
We are happy to announce that we are adding new rewards and updating existing ones – for example, everyone who gets (or has already done so) a ticket via the campaign, will get the show's booklet signed by Nadya free of charge!
We are also delighted to announce that acclaimed artists and long-term Pussy Riot collaborators The Connor Brothers have donated an edition of signed limited edition prints. See the rewards page to find out more!

In one week, thanks to all of you, we have achieved almost 40% of our funding goal!  
We've received some incredible press coverage of our project. Take a look at some of the articles:
Rolling stone: http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/pussy-riot-to-launch-experimental-theater-project-inside-pussy-riot-w493695
A huge, huge thank you to all of you who have supported our project in the first 24 hours!

campaign.story:
XOCHIPILLI ART INSTALLATION
PLAY

animation by Karen Del Valle 
In Aztec mythology Xochipilli was a God of art, games, painting, writing, beauty, bohemia, altered states of mind and creativity. We have been invited by Burning Man to install on the Playa our sculpture of Xochipilli to celebrate a deep cultural trip in the desert of Nevada this year.  
With support we will be able to take this installation for a week to Black Rock City, AUG 27—SEPT 4, where it will become a temple of creativity, radical self expression, plastic arts, visual performances, music and dance. 
  PLAY

 3D-scan and video by Dimensión N
Based on the 3D-scanned model (by Dimensión N) of the real statue currently housed in the National Museum of Anthropology in Mexico City, it was designed and built at KanoShop.mx, LED lights programmed by OOSPP. 
GIF by KanoShop.mx 
Both inside and outside, the sculpture is designed to give a new spiritual, physical and mental experience. It's our own contemporary interpretation of the cult that the sacred image of the original figure of Xochipilli carries within. 
This piece has been conceived to become an interactive image of the God that embraces all the artistic expressions as sacred.
After Burning Man we're hoping to present Xochipilli at various events and venues in Mexico and worldwide. Its elaborately processed polygonal white skin will become a canvas for new media artists. 
  mapping by Ze Effect   
XOCHIPILLI STATUE 
photo of the Statue of Xochipilli (National Museum of Anthropology, Mexico City) by @jeremycrandell
The original statue is of a single figure seated on a temple-like base, head tilted up, eyes open, jaw tensed, with his mouth half open and his arms opened to the heavens. Both the statue and the base upon which it sits are covered in carvings of sacred and psychoactive organisms including tobacco, mushrooms and various hallucinogenic, inebriating plants, commonly known as “power plants” (plantas de poder). 
graphic design by Rodrigo Kano 
Xochipilli undoubtedly represents not simply the Prince of Flowers but more specifically the Prince of Inebriating Flowers, including the mushrooms that, in Nahuatl poetry, were called "flowers that intoxicate". Known as curative and sacred, these plants were used in shamanic rituals for “healing the soul” and making people “connect” — which, we believe, is the main purpose of our artwork.  
WHO WE ARE  
logo by Mocre 
Collaboration is a mode of radical self-expression. Be a part of Xochipeople crew, make your contribution today! 
Any kind of your support will:
● Make makers make… ● Provide more opportunities for interactive art and related events ● Inspire new ideas and actions through art ● Make the experience of Burning Man accessible to more people in Mexico ● Make the experience of Mexican culture accessible to more people all over the world ● Provide a nifty reward in return.
OUR GIFTS
‘The act of gift giving is one of Burning Man’s ten core principles. It is a reflection of our community’s culture on and off the playa. Gifting has been the source of delight, wonder and happiness and it has bound our community together in surprising ways’ (Burning Man).
Plus every donation will be rewarded with a ¡Muchas gracias! eCard (via email), 'Your Name on Xochipilli' and a Sticker with Xochipeople logo. 
Although we'd love to deliver all your rewards, some of our pledges do not include shipping (international shipping, especially). Please, contact us to find out the delivery rates to your region xochipeople@gmail.com. 
PROJECT COSTS & NEEDS 
Main structure/Body (CNC-Laser Cuts, 4x8ft 15mm MDF) — 20,000 MXN
Golden Mask (CNC Cuts, Papier-Mâché) — 7,500 MXN
Skull — 7,500 MXN
Interactive Light Installation — 35,000 MXN
Power Plant (Solar or/and Fuel Generators, incl. Fuel for 10 days) — 20,000 MXN
Tools and Consumables (Hardware) — 20,000 MXN
Souvenirs for Burners — 5,000 MXN 
Movie from the Burning Man about Xochipilli — 5,000 MXN  
Shipping CDMX-BRC-CDMX — generously provided by our friends Mayan Warrior.  
TOTAL BUDGET 120,000 MXN (Approx. 6,500 USD)
In-kind Support in Mexico City: 
Laser cuts (hrs.) — for the wooden joints
Volunteers for assembling, disassembling, testing and packing 
*You can also make a tax deductible donation and be issued a tax receipt.
Please, contact us at: xochipeople@gmail.com
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
By now, we made a good progress, but the main part of production is still ahead: skull, mask, programmed and CNC-carved Power Flower tattoos, etc. Much of the machining, a lot of cuts, lighting installation and its tests (with OOSPP and Mayan Warrior) are to be done in ONE month, but every day we’re getting closer to having all of its elaborate skin and wooden joints ready for being assembled together in one piece. That’s why we ask you to support our project as much as you can. 

ONLY WITH YOUR CONTRIBUTION WE CAN BRING THIS ART TO BURNING MAN!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
What up, Xochipeople!
We've been crazy working here lately, every day at the 'dust factory', restlessly)) We had people from the Milenio TV channel, had a crew of brave volunteers from Xochipilli Club Cannabico, some dear friends giving their precious help; and the most important work — our backers! Thank you, guys, only with your support this all can work out!))
Now keep your fingers crossed, we're finishing our cuts in the next two days (*praying) before the delivery day of Mayan Warrior; we've had a very few of the assembling tests with our volunteers at KanoShop — will have to assemble the rest of it (=experiment with that) on the Playa — will have to find eager builders to make it happen (dear Universe, I hope you're reading this); have purchased some electrics and hardware — still will have to find a power plant (yeah-yeah, the 'prince of "plantas de poder" without power plant, jeje); OOSPP have successfully tested a part of their light installation — now we just need to buy the rest of it;), and THE FACE! our beautiful golden mask is getting there, two more layers — of patience and inspiration jiji — we're so excited to see how it's gonna look! Hoping, you are, too;)

updates.update_userinfo: a little correction of the glyph identifications
updates.update_content:
Thanks to one of our followers, Douglas J.Trainor, we seem to have now more appropriate identification for the flower glyphs of Xochipilli. 
In his email Douglas J. Trainor says: 'I just wrote you about two of the glyph identifications being incorrect. What you call a butterfly is actually a moth. Manduca sp. and likely Manduca sexta (tobacco hawkmoth). What you call Psilocybe cubensis is actually Psilocybe aztecorum, which can be found nearby where Xochipilli was found...'

campaign.story:
Graphic representation
 Burning Man, the annual gathering of ethereal wanderers is always the most inspiring and life-affirming event of the year for me. You may recall my previous neon installations: You Are Exactly Where You Need To Be, What You Seek is Seeking You, and Stay Present from the past three events. For 2017, I hope to return to the Playa, with a very important message for all of humanity: Everything You Need Is Inside You.
 Imagine: a massive handwritten neon, spanning 13 feet (4m) emitting a subtle turquoise hue across Burning Man’s vast desert-scape. The truism reflects Burning Man’s incredible communal spirit and represents the ancient teachings of the Sufi mystic Rumi - everything you need is inside you. It serves as a reminder to my fellow Burners, and to all human beings, that whilst we are often seeking external comforts, distraction and pleasure, we can harness our full potential by looking inwards: by drawing the strength and wisdom we need from our inner selves. Look no further - All the answers are inside you.
With your help, I can bring this installation into fruition. Our goal of $25,000 will support myself and my brilliant team to cover production, power, transportation, installation, and all material costs associated with a large scale structure of this kind in the extreme desert environment.
HERE IS OUR BUDGET BREAKDOWN:
If we meet our goal of $25,000 then $6,600 will go to the the Kickstarter fees and rewards. That leaves us with $18,400 for the project.
25K Budget
Neon production and crating - $7,500
Generator $1,000
Materials $1,000
metal frame and fence - $2,000
Installers crew and labor - $3,000
Temporary storage - $400
Transportation - $3,500
Rewards - $4,500
Kickstarter fees - $2,100
Each backer will receive a special thank you and exclusive Olivia Steele gift, so please take a moment to glance over the column on the right and decide on a pledge level! We worked very hard to design and produce some very exciting gifts!    
GIFT UPDATE 18/07/17
Take a souvenir of The Playa home with you forever with an incredible print of this year’s neon installation, on either an Olivia Steele™ scarf, towel or blanket!
Simply pledge either $300 for a Towel, $500 for a Scarf, or $700 for a blanket, and after the campaign you can let us know that you would like to choose the Burning Man installation print! 
STRETCH GOALS  
If we manage to exceed our goal, I’ll resurrect my custom Roadsigns from the Public Displays of Awareness series and bring them to this year’s Burning Man. 
Ready to install P.D.A. at BM 2016. Let's bring them back in 2017!
  Stay Present, 2016 Installation View
  Want to jump on this crazy train? We'd love to have you on board. Look to the right of the page for ways you can help us!
  Thank you so much, we couldn’t do any of this without you!
We would be so thankful if you would consider sharing the campaign and spreading the word. 

Share on Facebook
Share on Twitter
Share on Google+
Share on LinkedIn
OH YEAH... AND THERE IS ONE MORE REWARD...
We are offering rewards for sharing the campaign and spreading the word! Just click on the Kickbooster banner below and get the loot!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
WHAT DOES IT TAKE TO INSTALL A NEON IN THE DESERT?

Imagine installing an artwork in outer space.

The entire transportation and installation logistics need to be meticulously planned and carefully handled, as Burning Man is many miles away from the nearest city and supply center. 

It’s delicate, it’s glass and it’s electric. The challenges of installing hand blown glass sections piece by piece with the guaranteed elements of heat, wind and sandstorms during the installation are many. This means that installing in this harsh environment requires us to be well prepared. Working with glass and high voltage electrical components lends itself to highly skilled installers, and we’ve got them!

We have successfully accomplished this twice before, and we've learned a lot from the many obstacles of previous desert installs. We come this year better equipped than ever before, and with a fantastic team to help realise this project with flying colors! We're pumped and ready to go!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Phoenicopterus Rex is a gigantic replica of a pink plastic lawn flamingo. At 40 feet tall and 20 feet long, she will be the largest flamingo sculpture in the world, and probably the most absurd lawn ornament ever constructed. For us, this project is a dream come true, and we're grateful for your help!
We're already working hard on construction in San Francisco, in preparation for her debut at Burning Man 2017. There she will act as the centerpiece for various events, including a barbecue, parade, and burlesque show, to name a few. Brave Burners can climb atop her back, a thrilling 28 feet above the Playa floor. Timider Burners can enjoy lawn games on the surrounding astroturf, including bocce, cornhole, croquet, and maybe lawn darts.
For updates on build progress with pretty pictures, see the Updates tab.
Find us on The Web, Facebook, or Instagram.
To express our gratitude for your generous donation, we have rewards to offer:
  P-Rex will have a skeleton of wood and steel, skin of fiberglass, and legs of steel. The body will consist of two major pieces, constructed in San Francisco and combined in Black Rock City. We're working with a professional structural engineer (and Burner) on the design, so she should be rock solid.
We plan to transport P-Rex (including lawn and fence) to Burning Man via two stake bed trucks. These are three-axel vehicles, and no special driver's license is needed, so our volunteers will drive.
Our costs break down roughly like this:
We're lucky to get build space, some equipment, and lots of volunteer time for free.
 The party doesn't need to stop with a simple giant flamingo. With more funds, there is so much more we can do:
$15,000: Tutu. Tutu Tuesday is a time-honored tradition on the Playa, and with some extra scratch, we can outfit our bird in a giant rainbow tutu.
$20,000: Laser Eyes. With more money, Mingo can light up the night sky with wacky fluttering lasers shooting from both eyes.
$25,000: Onesie. Wow! With this much scratch, we can also celebrate Onesie Wednesday. We'd love to hear your ideas for the onesie; so far giraffe is our favorite.
$50,000: Pair of Flamingos. Holy Mother! Don Featherstone originally designed two different flamingo poses, and we can build both with this much money.
P-Rex in Stretch Goal Tutu
    Josh Zubkoff is the artist and mastermind behind Phoenicopterus Rex. His first major Burning Man art project was Wings in 2016, which also appeared at the World's Fair Nano in San Francisco, and received the FnF Summer Art Grant. Other contributors include:
Molly Shelestak: Project Manager. Project lead and organizer, scheduling, website, social media, and team morale.
Rodrigo De Lima: Graphic Designer. Project logo, overall brand, and creation of special edition poster for backer rewards.
Brigid Hughes: Speaker. Public speaker and promoter for events.
Srikanth Guttikonda: Transport Lead. Ensures we get the project to and from the Playa safely.
Jon Dye: Chef. Event coordinator, performance artist, and grumpy grillmaster.
Cody Smith: Instigator. Design consultant, campaign collaborator, accountant, and backer zero.
Build Team: Alex Morrison-Rusas, Cassie Ott, Michael Zee, and Chase Brignac.
Are you excited yet?! Boing Boing is. So is Anorak!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
There are many potential setbacks during construction and transportation of this giant bird. In particular, if the legs are damaged in shipping, we might not be able to loft her into the air at Burning Man. In that case, we'd set her nesting on the ground instead.

If her back proves slippery or otherwise fall-prone, we might not be able to allow climbing on the Playa. In this case, we'll simply have to admire the flamingo from below.

If we cannot secure appropriate food permits, we might not be able to host our barbeque event. In that case it'll be BYO meat.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Hey folks, we're back with a new project!
Q: Why are there so many songs (aka Playa art sculptures) about rainbows? 
A: There aren’t. I mean, there are lot of songs, but there’s only one 75 foot wide, 30 foot high, and 27,000 LED bedecked Playa rainbow in 2018: the Rainbow Bridge.

campaign.story:
Whatever your creed your reliance on the sun is unquestionable.
We have worshipped it as a God.
Spent lifetimes studying it through science.
Yet human hands will never touch its surface.
Celestial Field brings our sun to the Playa for us to dance in its glory.
Triggering our own solar flare.
Celestial Field - A Field of Light
As a collective with members ranging from Architecture Students to Structural Engineers, Coders to Electricians we have received partial funding to bring our interactive, solar inspired lighting installation to the Playa of Black Rock City and Burning Man this summer.
Celestial Field - Team
This is your opportunity to join the team on our first (but hopefully not last) new and exciting venture bringing the playful wonderment of our childhood back to earth with modern technology!
Celestial Field aims to capture the intangible awe the sun once held and make it accessible through modern mediums, combining two worlds; science and enchantment, embedding them on the Playa at Black Rock City, Nevada, for people to explore and lose themselves in.
Celestial Field - Sun Spot to System
  Celestial Field - Concept Development
A sea of swaying rods made from mirrored tubes mounted on springs form an undulating field, rising high above your head, and falling like the plasma pulled in all directions by the phenomenal magnetic forces found on our sun. By day, a field of mirrors intensify the suns natural beauty. Creating a maze of ever changing light to explore and push through, forging your own paths through the densest areas of Celestial Field, parting rods like magnets repelling polarised iron.
At sunset everything transforms. The field morphs, bursting into a sea of light reacting through sensors to movement, creating tracks of swirling light mimicking the fluid, almost pulsing nature of the suns corona.
Celestial Field - Rod Prototyping
  Celestial Field - Rod Prototyping
What was once worshipped as a distant god and celestial being can now exist on the surface of the earth as a Celestial Field in Nevada. The sun has risen and set, bringing with it heat and light; powering life on earth since the dawn of time, a focus of incomprehensible wonder and fascination for each and every culture across the globe. Celestial Field intends to reignite our faith in the intangible, while showing us there are powers and beauty still to be explored in the modern world.
Please help us bring this solar dream to life at Burning Man 2017, although partially funded by Burning Man we still need the help of an inspired community to get us across the Atlantic and lighting up the desert! Any and all backers will be much appreciated so take a look at our beautiful rewards and please please donate anything you can to help us along on this inspiring journey to Black Rock City!!!
Celestial Field - Logo and Thank You's
  Celesial Field - Jewellery
  Celesial Field - Jewellery
  Celetial Field - Clothing
  Celetial Field - Clothing
  Celestial Field - Frames
THANK YOU X
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We are confident that we will be able to share our installation with you and the people of Burning man however projects of this scale always pose their own challenges.

Material and fabrication costs are high due to the project's layered complexities. All materials, tools and resources have to be purchased in advance of the build to allow the projects to run smoothly and all prefabrication must be carefully pre-arranged to ensure all parts are in order on arrival at the playa.

The logistics of getting a finished proposal to site is also extremely challenging, especially with an internationally based team. Transportation to site of materials, tools, camp, people and food will be a logistical challenge and require high levels of organisation. 

With an intensely electrical project like this one transportation and storage of all materials must be carefully planned in advance to ensure no damage caused to any of the components.

There is a lot of hard work and energy ahead but, by working together, and most importantly, with your help, we are confident we will get this done.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
PARTICIPANT PRESS is in the final phase of publishing M Lamar, NEGROGOTHIC, the first anthology of writing on the work of artist, countertenor, and composer, M Lamar, including librettos and artwork by the artist. You can help us reach this goal, which began on the occasion of Lamar’s first solo exhibition at PARTICIPANT INC, NY, and travelled to the San Francisco Art Institute, our publishing partner for this book. 
Encompassing the past ten years of work, the book includes Lamar's most recent project, Funeral Doom Spiritual, which opened in New York to acclaim. As The New York Times described it, "this otherworldly, goth-tinged projection into the distant future of our violent, racially and sexually charged present offers a space of melancholic, alluring, ultimately stirring reflection."
The publication will feature artwork, librettos, and lyrics from Lamar’s major works, alongside essays by Sarah Bay-Cheng, Sabin Calvert, T.L. Cowan, Tucker Culbertson, Lia Gangitano, Ron Gregg, Jane Ursula Harris, Brandon Peter Masterman, Hesse McGraw, and Nayelli Portillo; and interviews with Lamar’s twin sister, transgender activist and actress Laverne Cox. Designed by Klaus Kempenaars of xSITE, the design is strongly influenced by pamphlets used for slave auctions and anti-slavery meetings during the Antebellum period. 
ISBN 978-0-9802324-9-3. 144 pages, edition of 1500.
Your support will enable us to complete this publication for launch this Fall 2017.
In a moment in which prevailing cinematic depictions offer only narrow historical accounts of subjugation, Lamar remembers well bell hooks' critique of “images of black men in popular culture that represent them as not only eager to ‘do it for daddy’ but, even more, as individuals tortured by […] ‘unrequited longing for white male love.’” Lamar engages this fictive fantasy and turns it on it's head examining white historical and cultural violent, fetishistic, and cannibalistic acts against black persons as well as white imaginings of blackness via popular culture.
“For every person who wants to be free,” Lamar has noted, “an exorcism (or process of decolonization) is necessary.” Longing is a part of this process. 
Lamar’s work mixes romanticism with horror – the horror is American white supremacy. At the center of NEGROGOTHICISM is the Negro Antichrist: rock star, blues man, like Screamin’ Jay Hawkins, with a big, operatic voice, and a deep connection to the supernatural. Born in Mobile, Alabama, Lamar draws inspiration from Southern gothic traditions, as well as underground, goth, and post punk music. Lamar states, “From the slave ship to the pillory… on plantations and lynching trees… within and beyond the prison and the grave… NEGROGOTHIC binds archive to myth, merging bodily properties with supernatural possession.”
Founded in 2001 as an educational corporation and not-for-profit alternative space, PARTICIPANT INC seeks to provide a venue in which artists, curators, and writers can develop, realize, and present ambitious projects within a context that recognizes the social and cultural value of artistic experimentation. By encouraging experimentation and project-based exhibitions for artists at many different stages of their careers, PARTICIPANT INC strives to address the changing context of alternative arts presenting and to respond responsibly to the diverse practices of artists.
     Why Kickstarter?
While PARTICIPANT receives annual funding for our exhibitions and public programs from government, foundation, and individual sources, our publishing initiatives require additional support, which is not a given. With commissioning, editing, and design nearly complete, your gift will provide finishing funds to aid with printing and distribution costs.
This project has been selected for inclusion on Art Basel’s curated page on Kickstarter.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Due to our extensive experience working on artist books under the auspices of PARTICIPANT PRESS, as well as related co-publishing efforts in conjunction with D.A.P., Regency Arts Press, and Vox Populi, Philadelphia, PARTICIPANT INC is uniquely positioned to ensure the successful completion of "M Lamar, NEGROGOTHIC."

Working closely with artist M Lamar, collaborators and writers, as well as graphic designer, Klaus Kempenaars of xSITE, and printer, Dusty Hollensteiner of Publicide, Inc., our team is committed to realizing the publication this fall. We have a decades-long working relationship with Kempenaars, with whom we’ve produced several publications, in addition to all organizational and exhibition-related graphics and our website. 

The most common risk we have experienced in the past is time. Books can take a lot longer than expected to print, generally due to cost overages after the Kickstarter campaign is over. These can include increased printing, shipping, and distribution costs. Our diversified funding sources for this project guarantee that unforeseen expenses can be met. We receive consistent support from government agencies and foundations, including the New York State Council for the Arts; the Department of Cultural Affairs; the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts; Lambent Foundation; among many others. The Harpo Foundation has provided support specifically for the project. 

In the years that PARTICIPANT PRESS has been operating, over eight publications have been printed and distributed, from the exhibition catalogue, “Dead Flowers," to Kathe Burkhart’s illustrated novella, “The Double Standard,” and her companion collection of short stories, “Dudes.”
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Dear Supporters,
We are so grateful for your partnership in making M Lamar's NEGROGOTHIC possible, and thank you for your patience while we fulfill your reward. These books required some hand assembly, and Lamar will be signing the finished books tomorrow, so they will be mailed in the coming week. Your copy is on it's way!
Thank you!!

As a result of the overwhelming support from our backers, we're thrilled to include an additional chapter in NEGROGOTHIC! The final chapter will feature Funeral Doom Spiritual and a conversation with M. Lamar on the occasion of his exhibition, Funeral Doom Spiritual, at the ONE Archives at the USC Libraries in LA, and in conjunction with Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Medium at LACMA and the Getty Museum. The inclusion of this chapter brings the book more up to date and presents an exciting turn toward the future in Lamar’s current work. We expect to print the book with the additional chapter this summer and our new release date will be in September.

campaign.story:
Perfect City is launching a 20-year art and advocacy project this fall, with performances, workshops, photo exhibition and more. 
Perfect City at Prelude 2016 Festival, photo (c) Paula Court
Perfect City is a collective of NYC residents - artists, activists, students and planners -  that creates long-term creative strategies to respond to displacement and gentrification. We are a think tank, an arts collective, and we mix activism, urbanism and creativity. We want us all to be able to live together more equitably. 

After a year of research and a few performances, we are producing a two-week celebration of our neighborhood at Abrons Arts Center this fall, and we need your support. 
WHO IS PERFECT CITY?
Perfect City Working Group, 2017
Perfect City includes: Gisela Andras, Jamel Ayala, Mallory Catlett, Angela Choi, Grace Chung, Tyler Diaz, Jim Findlay Jay Koo, Jaime Maitin, Gabriella Marrero, Nola Sporn Smith, Jahmorei Snipes, Tiffany Zorrilla. 
We are a intelligent, rowdy and discursive mix of idea-makers, art-makers and thinkers who care a lot about this place. We all have a history with this neighborhood. Some of our families have been here for generations, some of us moved here and changed the place when we arrived. 
The project was started by playwright and Guggenheim Fellow Aaron Landsman, who saw a pattern in the cities and neighborhoods where he lived and worked. Public officials tout their metro areas' "sustainability," pointing to things like farmers' markets, bike lanes and other conveniences that speak to progressive values, but the cities themselves become unaffordable to all but the wealthy. 
From our research with urban planners, we learned that city kids don't usually go into the planning fields, and most cities are planned by suburbanites.  So we set out to build a project, a movement and a sea change. Cities by city people. 
WHY US?
People who grow up in cities are born urban planners. We have to be. We ride public transit from day one; we use creative strategies to navigate invisible and visible boundaries between neighborhoods; we know how to avoid and how to belong. Somehow, though, our needs and our narratives are not at the table when decisions are being made about zoning and planning.  So Perfect City is bringing our own chairs, making a new table, whatever it takes. 
Zoned Out! Book Launch at Abrons Arts Center, sponsored by Perfect City, 2017
 WHAT YOU'RE SUPPORTING
Perfect City's launch includes two weeks of programming  at Abrons, in their main gallery, and in the Experimental Theater. Our programming will include guided Urban Observer walking tours, live rock and roll, mapping exercises, and talks with activists, artists and more.
Here's what your contribution funds:
Artists' and speakers' fees for panels and shows
Attendance at all events is pay-what-you-can 
Urban Observer Walks and Avoidance Mapping 
You're Next printing and production 
The Perfect City launch is about making room for views that are often cleaned up when the city is gentrified. 
OUR NEIGHBORHOOD
We’re based on the Lower East Side and Chinatown. Even if you are not from here, a lot of families in the US have a history with this place. It’s like a microcosm of America: diverse, vibrant, complicated, rich in history. And it’s changing. Fast. Our neighborhood feels like it’s disappearing before our eyes. 
Lower East Side, Photo by Haruka Sakaguchi, 2017 all rights reserved
And even if you’ve never set foot on our sidewalks, you’ll recognize what’s happening here because it’s probably happening in your city too, no matter where you live. 
When diverse neighborhoods are rebranded as luxury destinations and unique small businesses are replaced by cookie-cutter galleries and boutiques, it’s time to come up with a new way to stay.
20 YEARS
Yes. 
There are a lot of great art projects that try to change the world in a month, in a year, or maybe two. Perfect City is saying that the problems are big, the solutions have to be, too, and it's going to take some time. 
We have big goals - we want our working group members to run for public office, to become planners and architects themselves, and to change laws and culture. That isn't something we can do overnight. This is the beginning. 
WHAT WE DO
We meet every week - we learn about zoning, planning and displacement, and we create projects with what we find out. Here are a few things we're working on for the fall:
From "Original New Yorkers" By Haruka Sakaguchi, (c) all rights reserved
ORIGINAL NEW YORKERS – Perfect City working group member's Haruka Sakaguchi’s award-winning photography and text series of New Yorkers’ experiences with displacemenet is beautiful, stark and challenging. It will be in the main Abrons Arts Center gallery for our fall launch. 
URBAN OBSERVER WALKS – working group member and Abrons Staffer Jaime Matlin has been watching the city evolve since he was a kid. He has a three-generation lineage on the Lower East Side. At our fall launch he’ll be creating unique observational walks in the neighborhood, which will reveal hidden sites of safety, contemplation and creativity. You’ll leave knowing how to be an urban observer, whether it’s your first time here or you’ve been here the whole time.
Working group member Jamel Ayala teaching Avoidance Mapping at Crossing The Line 2016
 AVOIDANCE MAPPING - this came out of a meeting this fall. It's a way to identify unconscious bias, unearth the sophisticated ways we know about where to go and who to steer clear of, and how there are many cities mapped onto one concrete location. Avoidance Mapping was recently the subject of a workshop with architects and planners at the Architectural League, and a forthcoming article on Urban Omnibus.
Roundtable Performance, (c) Paula Court, all rights reserved.
ROUNDTABLE PERFORMANCES - Last fall, as part of the Crossing The Line Festival, presented by FIAF/The French Institute, we presented roundtable performances for audiences that included our neighbors, visitors from Berlin and other cities, planners and arts audiences. These roundtables included facts and figures about gentrification and zoning, provocations to become better activists, as well as songs, multilingual dialogues and conversations. This form will be part of our fall roll-out at Abrons. 
Perfect City Roundtable Performance, photo by Paula Court (c) all rights reserved
YOU’RE NEXT -  working group member Gabriella Marerro was walking down Grand Street one day, remarking on the businesses that had closed or were about to. She looked at her favorite Cuchifritos and thought, "You're next." At the hipster coffee shop: "You're next." At the pizza spot. At the florist, the gallery, the affordable housing. And so we came up with this campaign we'll be rolling out this fall at our launch. You're Next is a poster made by visual artist Daniel Bejar for store windows throughout the neigborhood, and a series of conversations among business owners so that we can all see ourselves in solidarity with each other, rather than in competition. Maybe you're next to join us!
****
ABOUT HENRY ST SETTLEMENT/ABRONS ARTS CENTER
For over 124 years, Henry Street Settlement has served its community in the Lower East Side to create opportunity, unity, conversation, and a well-balanced life. Henry Street continues to explore effective and adventurous programming like Perfect City to fulfill this mission. By incorporating a variety of tactics, Perfect City continues to bring unity, voice, and strength to residents of the LES. As with Henry Street Settlement and Abrons Arts Center, Perfect City uses multi-disciplinary, layered, bold, and visionary programs as the vehicle to drive conversations among people who would not otherwise discuss their similar and different viewpoints. Together, HSS and Perfect City can create synchronization between housing, health, education, urban planning, and the arts to keep the LES neighborhood dynamic, welcoming, and empowered. Henry Street/Abrons Info:
As one of the nation’s first settlement houses, Henry Street Settlement was established in 1893 with a mission to open doors of opportunity for Lower East Side residents and other New Yorkers through social services, arts, and health care programs. Each year, HSS continues to help over 60,000 New Yorkers reach their full potential through innovative, inclusive, integrated, and high-impact programs and services throughout our 17 sites on the LES. HSS serves this community through four program areas: Health & Wellness, Transitional & Supportive Housing, Education & Employment, and Visual & Performing Arts.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Even if we don't reach our goal, the fall launch of Perfect City will happen as planned. We'll give our time generously, we'll raise money through more traditional means, and we will rely on Abrons Arts Center for more in-house production help; we already have a small fee in the bank from Abrons.

The whole budget for our fall launch is $36,000. Abrons is contributing $5,000 in cash and another $7,000 in in-kind support (free space, publicity, and production help). Aaron Landsman's Guggenheim Fellowship will pay for his time on the fall launch. 

Perfect City founder Aaron Landsman has a long history of getting large and small-scale performance and other works done. He's a current Guggenheim Fellow, a former Princeton Arts Fellow, and has received major awards and commissions in the US and abroad. Perfect City has received grants already from the Graham Foundation, LMCC, The Rubin Foundation and several individual contributors. We'll be going back to these and other funders this summer. 

The $11,000 we are trying to raise here is both significant to our bottom line and an important signal that arts activism, and the voices of people in this neighborhood, are worth supporting.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: Perfect City's Fall Launch Is Three Weeks Away!
updates.update_content:
Hello Kickstarter contributors!
Perfect City’s fall launch is three weeks away! Will you come join us? 
October 26-28 and November 2-4 at Abrons Arts Center, we want you in the conversation with us. 
MAKE RESERVATIONS HERE: 
http://www.abronsartscenter.org/on-stage/shows/aaron-landsman-perfect-city-fall-2017/

Dear Perfect City Backers - 
This morning our Kickstarter campaign closed successfully - we are 105% funded and so grateful to you for backing Perfect City's fall launch at Abrons Arts Center. Your support means so much to us at this time. We received 199 pledges of support from three continents and more than 15 states. You are joining us at the beginning of a 20-year movement, a real journey that harnesses a collaborative artistic process toward agency, inclusion and leadership for cities by city people.

Hi delightful Perfect City supporters.
We are doing a brief, bilingual (Spanish/English) shout out to you and introduction to our working group tonight at 7:30PM EST. Feel free to tune in live, or watch the recording when it's done. 
https://live.kickstarter.com/perfect-city/live/perfect-city-bilingual-shout-out-and-intro

Dear most excellent backers - we are a week and $2300 away from successfully funding the Perfect City fall launch. Today and tomorrow another match is in effect, so if there is anyone you would be willing to reach out to, who you think might be down with our cause, it's a great time to drop them a line. 
https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/711603567/perfect-city-fall-launch-2017
Perk of the day: Our working group's map of the LES and Chinatown, with an eye on spaces you can go to or patronize, that celebrate the diversity and history of the neighborhood.

updates.update_userinfo: We are growing together - 10 days to go!
updates.update_content:
Perfect City's fall launch is coming together. We are more than 150 backers strong, and we'd love if each of you would share this project with some folks. We're in the home stretch, with less than $3,000 to raise in 10 days. We can do this and we'd love your help. 
The project continues to grow as the campaign does - last week we had a small teach-in, where working group members each took a reading about displacement, history, zoning and other subjects and taught them to the group. It was dynamite. Here's a photo of Tiffany Zorrilla teaching about the racist history of zoning.

updates.update_userinfo: An ask, an article and an invitation

This is a big week for us. We are about 50% funded and we have a favor to ask, an invitation for you, and a new article online to tell you about. 
ASK

updates.update_userinfo: Kickstarter Week Two: a new reward from Bard Grad Center
updates.update_content:
Hello fabulous backers! 

We have come through our first week strong, with almost 40% of our goal met, thanks to you. It would be amazing if we can get to 50% by this weekend. Can you tell three people about our campaign?
A NEW REWARD
The next two backers at $50 or above get a late-breaking reward: two tickets to Noah Fuller's walking tour of Lower Manhattan, that discusses the ways elites have tried to retake the neighborhood in various ways across history.

Thank you all so much for your generous, righteous contribution. We hit 15% of our goal on the first day of our Kickstarter campaign thanks to you. The first week is really key for us in building momentum. Thank you for believing in us. Please share our page if you know folks who might be early adaptors like you.
Here is a quote from Perfect City founding working group member Angela Choi, about why she works with us. Angela is a LES/Chinatown-born Yale grad.

campaign.story:
Erie's favorite Festival turns 25 this summer and to celebrate, we're adding another full-day of performance art and family fun! This expansion requires more resources than in previous years. Our goal is raise at least $5,000 (and hopefully more!) to help pay for the extra production expenses and artist fees while keeping the price for attending the Festival the same as has been for 25 years – free!
To do this we've created several exclusive rewards for our backers that are designed to make your experience at the Festival more fun, and easier to enjoy. Many of these rewards will ONLY be available through this Kickstarter campaign – you will not be able to buy them at the Festival itself! Check out the music, scan through the rewards and back this project for the party of the summer!
This commemorative poster by Quinn Thompson includes 25 years of designs and is available exclusively through this Kickstarter campaign. Signed by John Vanco, it is a must have for collectors and fans alike!
      The Festival attracts more than 20,000 people eager to experience great music from regional talents to international superstars. This year is no different featuring bands as diverse as the hottest band in world music today, Mokoomba (see video above), to regional blues legends, Eric Brewer & Friends.  
Rodger Montgomery Blues Band and Mary Alice Brown Quartet were both featured at the first Erie Art Museum Blues & Jazz Festival 25 years ago. 
Live performance are on the main stage 2-10 on Saturday and 12-8 on Sunday. Click on the band profiles for more information! 
Saturday, August 5  
              Sunday, August 6
                     This festival is all about blues and jazz so we have a special treat just for Kickstarter backers.  We have put together an exclusive Kickstarter only 25th Anniversary Blues and Jazz Festival playlist featuring artists from all 25 years of the festival! This is a must for all those fans that have been attending the festival from the very start. 
We know you’re gonna want to be here all day, so we have made it even easier for you. Our stylish water koozy comes with its very own supply of unlimited water! No more lugging heavy coolers from a faraway parking space. Speaking of parking spaces, we also are offering a limited amount of convenient, guaranteed parking spaces close to the event. Be sure to jump on this opportunity as there are only a few available.  
    The Festival is very family friendly and there will be plenty of things for kids to do! This year the event is packed full of fun and engaging performances, including Art Acts, a amazing giant puppets and masks. 
Everyone will have also the opportunity to help paint a mural by Mark Weber (shown below), during a public paint day at the event. The Erie Philharmonic Jazz Instruments Petting zoo, an Ekphrastic Poetry Workshop, and many other activities including a special double-feature film from LEAF’s Movies at the Arboretum will all be at this year’s event. Of course, there will be plenty of bubbles to blow and ice-cream to eat.
Mural design by Mark Weber
Don’t miss out on buying cool stuff for the kids, like our exclusive t-shirts, and keep them rocking out to the music with their very own inflatable guitars. Both items are available in our Family Pack! 
The Prime Real Estate reward offers a canopy tent set-up and stocked with Festival merch including a cooler full of necessities. The tent will be in front of the general public tent line, and offers a great view of the stage.  
  Canopy tent will be set up with a perfect view of the stage.
  2017 Kickstarter exclusive blue t-shirt designed by Shelby Kirk with creative direction by Shelle Barron.
  We’ve featured a lot of the rewards available. Here are all the reward tiers that we are offering to make your experience at the Festival even better.
  Infographic designed by Monica Gustin
  A special thanks to the following folks who helped to bring this Kickstarter campaign to life: Megan Ciafre, Jacob Poteet, Monica Gustin, Quinn Thompson, Colleen Dougan, Kristan Wheaton, and the Erie Art Museum staff. 
The Erie Art Museum Blues & Jazz Festival is truly a team effort, and would not be possible without the help of several individuals, local businesses, and community organizations. Thank you to our sponsors:
Abigail Adams & Lauder Greenway, Acclaim Electric, Agility Marketing, Allburn Florist, Associated Clinical Laboratories: A Quest Diagnostics Affiliate, Beer & Pop Discount Warehouse, Cascade Park Club, CAT-TV, Charles & Rose Schlaufman, Chipotle, Circolo Nazionale Lodge 122, Connoisseur Media, Constellation, Counseling & Assessment Services, Country Fair, Dahlkemper Lanscape and Architects, Donald & Marjorie Inderlied, Douglass-Bennett, E.C.G.R.A., Edinboro University, Emergycare, Epic Web Studios, Erie Arts & Culture, Erie Beer Company, Erie Community Foundation, Erie Ice Works, Erie Insurance, Erie Reader, Frontier Pharmacy Inc., Giant Eagle, Greengarden Place, Hagan Business Machines Inc., Hanes Erie, Inc., Harborcreek Giant Eagle, In Memory of George & Elizabeth Ferretti, Jane & Gil Asher, Jazz Erie, Jim & Sharon Stoik, Jim Spiegel, John Hilbert Sr. Family, Karen Carns, Kat Creative Signs, Kenneth Burkhart, Kevin & Susan O'Connell, Key Bank, Like My Thai, Little Caesars, Dickey's Barbecue Pit, Lynn & Dale McBrier, Lowe's Home Improvement on Asbury Road, Marshall & Theresa Fryer, Matt Mead Photography LLC, Mercyhurst University, Michael Butler, Modern Industries, Inc., PACA, Pamela Moore, Presque Isle Downs & Casino, Printing Concepts, Quickstarter, Ray Wakley RV, Richard & Jeanne Chapman, Romolo Chocolates, Scott Enterprises, Small Business Alternatives, Inc., Susan Black & Barry Weller, Ted Wood & Associates, The Otto B. Imig Fund of the Erie Community Foundation, Times Publishing Company, UPMC Health Plan, and WQLN.
Cheers to 25 years -
Emily Dauber
Producer, Erie Art Museum Blues & Jazz Festival

updates.update_content:
To every single one of our wonderful backers,
Thank you!
It has been a fantastic campaign and we are looking forward to providing each of you with your rewards.  Look for details from me in an update or email next week.
In the meantime, enjoy the "Best of the Fest" playlist and I look forward to seeing each of you next week at the Festival!

The campaign ends tonight at 11 PM.  We are hoping to break $7,000 by then.  Any last thing you can do to help would be greatly appreciated! 
I will post an update once the campaign is over to let you know more details about how and where to get your rewards.
In the meantime, let me say it one more time:  Thank you!!

First, let me say it again:
You are amazing!
We have received so much support and we really appreciate all your comments and emails and likes and shares and everything!  It has been a great campaign!
But it is not quite over.  We have about 48 hours left.  We would love to sell out our "#1 Fan" reward tier (2 left) and our "Prime Real Estate" reward tier (1 left).  If you know anyone who might be interested, please let them know that they are still available.

Good morning to all our amazing Backers!
Early yesterday morning, right after I sent out the last update, we met our goal of $5000!  It took us a little less than 48 hours to do it and right now we sit at $5165 with 14 days to go!
Thanks to everyone for your support!
But we aren't done, yet!  Every dollar we make now is a dollar that goes to support the Blues and Jazz Festival in the future.

To all our wonderful backers!
First, thank you for your support yesterday!  We met about 80% of our funding goal on the first day!  That is nothing short of amazing!
That was hardly all the good news we got yesterday, though.  If you take another look at the campaign page right now you will see a small green "K" below the video.  This means that Kickstarter has designated us a "Project Kickstarter Loves".  Only about 7% of all Kickstarter projects receive this designation.  Here is what Kickstarter says about how it picks the projects it loves:

campaign.story:
We're launching a magazine residency inside of Hello Mr. called 'The Issues.' Help us print the first issue of BRUNCHCLUB! 
Hello Mr. is a magazine about men who date men. We are a collective of artists and writers that reflect the diverse perspective of the LGBTQ community. When we launched in 2012, we sought to create a platform for emerging talent and unheard voices, and add to the momentum for more inclusive representation in media. With your help through our first Kickstarter, we brought Hello Mr. into the world.
Eight issues later, we are expanding that mission, and introducing an artist residency that propels the creators of tomorrow. We’re calling it The Issues. 
Using our global distribution experience and mentorship from industry leaders, we are providing the tools and resources to get new ideas from queer voices off the ground. We think of it as an academy for editors, art directors, and media-makers of the future. With your support, we will help launch our first magazine-in-residence, and distribute it inside the next issue of Hello Mr.
Meet our first magazine-in-residence!
BRUNCHCLUB is about the quest for truth, culture, and diversity within the LGBTQ community. The creators, Colby Anderson and Ernest Macias, are both 24-year olds and graduates of Texas State University. They are unapologetically “queer & hungry.”
Over the last few months, between shifts at McNally Jackson Bookstore in Soho, NYC, we have been working on their first issue which explores the lives of queer POC in unexpected corners of the country. You can expect poetry from the West Texan desert, a day-in-the-life account of a gender queer babe in Ohio, an exploration of the Latinx body in nature, a profile on Costa Rican model, activist, and artist Hazkel, and more.
We have a stellar team lined up for this collaboration––apart from the Hello Mr. team, BRUNCHCLUB is also being mentored by TeenVogue’s Phillip Picardi, Instagram's Jeffrey Gerson and Graphic Designer Nijel Taylor.
Why Kickstarter?
Returning to Kickstarter to launch The Issues residency is the perfect way to remind us of our original mission. We are more than a magazine, we're a community that believes changes happens from the ground up. And coming back as a Kickstarter Gold project helps us raise awareness for the new stories we want to tell with The Issues.
The funds raised will support the production costs of BRUNCHCLUB and allow it to be distributed inside the next issue of Hello Mr. later this Summer. And, if we exceed our current goal, Colby and Ernest will also join us at the printing facility to watch their first issue come to life on press!
What about future residents?
Applications for our next “Issue” will open this Fall. Anyone around the world with a great idea for a magazine will be able to apply. The goal is to produce two zines a year, aligning to the Hello Mr. publishing calendar. However, excess funds from this Kickstarter will also allow us to package our insights resources and develop the curriculum into an online course so anyone can learn how to make a zine too!
The role of print is to inform readers of important issues and inspire them to take action. And we believe that our responsibility, as creators, is more important than ever. Don't believe the hype, print is not dead. In fact, its independent presses and zines that continue to stir up social change throughout history. Let’s continue inspiring action together, one issue at a time.
Timeline
June / July - Finishing touches on BRUNCHCLUB & Hello Mr. issue 09
Early August - Print and produce the issues!
Late August - Open applications for our second residency
Early September - Shipping begins
Late September - BRUNCHCLUB launch party in Brooklyn, NY
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The Issues is a 12-week residency, designed to fit the publishing calendar of producing two new zines a year. Three months is a tight window of time to launch a magazine, so we will be relying on the selected mentors and an organized timeline of assignments to meet the deadline of each Issue. Additionally, we are keeping the residency open to anyone in the world, so residents will need to be comfortable with remote working styles and be able to communicate ideas effectively across time zones and geography. That said, we’ve definitely learned a lot working through the kinks with BRUNCHCLUB, and feel confident in welcoming the next resident into the fold this Fall.

We have a lot of experience in the print world already, but should any conflicts occur, our backers will be the first to know! Honest and open communication is the name of the game.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

And you'll get a one-year subscription to Hello Mr. as a Patron Member including the tote bag and all the lovely rewards mentioned above and a special recognition in the first issue of BRUNCHCLUB.

updates.update_userinfo: Launch party details & your PDF copy
updates.update_content:
We did it, y’all! The last few weeks were some of the longest days ever, but now that we’re passed the finish line we can finally take a few breaths and finish wrapping up the issue. We’d like to take this time to thank all of you once again so so SO much. We could not have done it without your generosity and support. Your contribution is funding the production of our first issue and giving a head start to future residents of The Issues, by Hello Mr.
Yesterday we photographed our cover star, Hazkel, a Costa Rican model/artist/activist and gender nonconformist. Over the coming weeks as we finish up the issue to print, we’ll be going behind-the-scenes on our Instagram account @BRUNCHCLUBNY, so make sure to follow along for all updates and a first look at the issue.

Hi again! This race to the finish line isn't over yet. You've been the best cheerleaders us queers could ask for, so thank you! Word seems to be catching on, because we've had some great press since we started. Check 'em out below: 
"Exploring My Queer Identity" on Huffpost
"Ryan Fitzgibbon on the Value of Vulnerability" on Kickstarter
"Raising funds for Zine Mentorship" on PAPER
"Hello Mr. Launches LGBTQ Magazine Residency" on STACK

We achieved our goal and couldn't have done it without all of your support. We are determined to keep queer print alive, and you’re part of that now too!
This means that we are one step closer to making BRUNCH CLUB's first issue a reality. Words can't begin to describe how excited and happy we feel.
So THANK YOU from the bottom of our queer lil' Texas hearts. We love you! Also a huge thank you to our dad, Ryan Fitzgibbon, and the amazing Hello Mr. team. Without their guidance and support we wouldn't be here. To our amazing mentors Nijel, Phillip, and Jeffrey, we are forever grateful for your selfless dedication and passion to our project.

Hey everyone! Colby and Ernest here, your first magazine-in-residence. We’d like to take a few minutes to thank you for your pledge and give you a brief update on our progress.
Last week we met our first mentor, Jeffrey Gerson via video conference from his office at the Instagram HQ in San Francisco. He walked us through some best practices on growing a readership using social media, and gave us a lot to think about as we start building this brand.

campaign.story:
Our Concept 
According to religious texts, Leviathan represents an enormous sea monster. In other stories, it also symbolizes a politically totalitarian state with a vast bureaucracy. We were inspired by this idea, but wanted to make something new and unique, so we wrote our own myth about a people, living in a harsh desert land, banding together to slay an oppressive murderous creature that lurked beneath the sand, the Nahtaivel. We then used this myth to inform the design of our sculpture, which represents the Nahtaivel in all aspects of its existence. It calls upon the viewer to be conscious of the struggles in their own realm, while recognizing the power of solidarity. You can read the full myth here!
The Sculpture
The Tomb will consist of three main components: the base, the tower, and the skeleton of the Nahtaivel. The base of the Tomb is an octagonal chamber, composed of faceted panels and gothic inspired archways, all supported by a modular steel structure. The walls of this chamber are decorated with a code, which tells the narrative of the tomb and leads the viewer through its interactive elements. A series of flying buttresses extend out and around this structure, creating the tower, around which the skeleton of the creature will rest. In the center of the tomb the skull of the beast, sits on an alter, and hidden its mouth is a decoder. Participant will use the decoder to translate a code and gain access to secret compartments, full of surprises. To add layer of interactivity, our friends from the House of Yes will be gracing the tomb with their talents during burn week.
 (from left to right, Eric Coolidge Hannah MacDonald & Eric Whitney)
Our Vision 
Bringing a large scale sculpture to Burning Man has been a goal of ours for a long time. As artists and fabricators we have always found inspiration at Burning Man (in the artwork and the incredible landscape) and as a part of the Burning Man community, we have always wanted to contribute and participate in this way. This year’s theme, Radical Ritual, demand some kind of temple, or place of worship, so we put our heads together and brainstormed a list of what this inspired in us.
What we have for you and where the money goes!
                     Want more than 1 prize? No problem.
Add the highest priced item, donate the total for all the items you want. Then send us a message including the list OR wait til we send out survey's at the end of the campaign and select the other gifts you pledged for! If you live in NYC.!
Budget Break down
The Tomb of Nahtaivel is an Honorarium Project, which has recieved partial funding from Burning Man, but we have a long ways to go. You can see what this 20k is going towards.
Build Materials- $3,500 
Hardware & Consumables - $1,000
CNC Work - $3,000
Lighting & Electrical - $2,500 
Power - $1,000
Hidden Compartment Components - $1,000 
Transportation - $8,000 
Total - $20,000
__________________________________
 Progress Update
7/20
PLAY

Almost all of the CNC plasma cutting and structural metal work it done! We have gothic arches assembled, and are working on putting the flying buttresses together today. Feels so good! Next week we'll start CNC milling the spine (vertabea by vertabrea) and painting!
 ______________________
7/23
Grateful to have Hannah, one of our project leads, back in the shop after two weeks of severe poison ivy! Also we started painting!!!!!!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Transportation: This is actually our biggest challenge. We are based in Brooklyn and our goal is to get everything to BRC in one 26ft box truck. This means everything has to pack flat and the total weight of our sculpture and tools has to be as minimal as possible. Those mountains are going to be ROUGH!

Time: We are racing the clock to fabricator all of the intricate peices of the sculpture in time to drive them to Black Rock City. We have an awesome crew of skilled artists and fabricators, but life happens. For example one of our designers got some serious poison oak exposure last week an hasn't been able to help build in a week. Luckily she is stil able to work digitally from home, but loosing a pair of hands at the shop hasn't helped our timeline.

Funding: Erecting a 25 ft scupture in the desert isn't exactly easy, but we're honestly less worried about that than raising the money to do it! Please share this page and spread the love!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

comments.content: Hi guys. Still not received my pledge.
Hi there! Are the clocks ever coming?...
Thank you for the coasters. I think I'm going to paint them in a variety of fun colors and seal them in a heat resistant resin. Should be fun.

Hi guys, on Feb. 28 I was told the leggings I had ordered would ship next week. On Mar 12 I was told you guys had missed the message but could send either the coasters or the leggings and just to let you know which I preferred. On Mar 13 I replied: "I'll take the leggings if they can ship this week. If not, then the coasters." Making it clear that I wanted a product in hand for the monies I paid. Six weeks later I have no product and no word. I know KS doesn't bind you to any actual delivery and the monies you were given have long ago been spent. I also know that "artists" have a solid reputation for over promising and under-delivering with a strong game of "There's been a bit of a glitch, but it should be next week." any time someone attempts to hold them accountable to their word. But, before you keep playing this game without any actual delivery of a product, I'm going to ask you to consider something. Every time this happens the people who were played remember. They remember names, they remember faces, and more than that they remember that "That group can't be trusted." I've back well over 100 KS's. In that group of KS's I've backed 5 movies, 3 of which I've never seen a product for years later. I no longer back movies. Ever. And I tell friends it's unlikely they will ever see a movie they back on KS so be careful when they back and that it's probably better if they back for a lesser amount as they're more likely to lose any money they pay. You're probably the 5th artist I've backed. Of that group, you are making the 3rd I've never seen a product from. It's not hard to guess how likely I am to back artists from now on.

Hi, I just wanted to touch base with you concerning my swag. I did get a message about my leggings, but that's the last I've heard in months. I'd like to change it back to the coasters if that would result in a deliverable product.
Best wishes!
CONGRATS YOU GUYS! I cannot wait to see it on the playa !!!!! Burn baby burn �
Nice work Guys! Super Cool design and my tshirt is gonna rock!
Congrats on your success! Wicked design! Will look absolutely amazing in the desert. Excited for more pics and updates along the way!
Yay!!!

campaign.story:
Aurel Klimt’s Laika is a touching tale of the relationship between humanity and the rest of the universe set against the backdrop of the frantic era of space exploration. After seven long years of exhaustive production, this 90 minute feature following the proud tradition of old Czech puppet masters is finally nearing completion.
But in order to finish its post-production and get Laika out there, we need your help. 
   “Laika’s plot may seem like a fairytale, but it’s far from that. Even though it operates within the realms of the genre, I always need to frame the story with elements from the real world. And some of Laika’s darker undercurrents will definitely speak more to an adult audience.” (Aurel Klimt)
Life is not easy for Laika, a stray dog living in the outskirts of a freezing Russian city. She spends her days relentlessly scouring the streets for food for her beloved and always hungry pups.
Winter in Soviet Russia. Laika scavenging for food.
One day, she’s captured and handed over to a research institute where she undergoes a drastic and rapid training that transforms her into a space explorer. And off she goes into the unknown, smuggling her pups in her spacecraft.
Soviet engineers examining their new astronaut.
Once they land on a mysterious planet called Qem, they find an extraterrestrial version of paradise.
Meanwhile, the tough fight of global powers over dominance has only begun. Russia sends its first envoy, astronaut and national hero Yuri Leftkin and another global superpower is soon to follow with their representative – a greedy specimen called Neil Knockout.
Neil Knockout (on the left) and Yuri Leftkin.
Soon, they arrive to Qem and the race to conquer space becomes a battle of rapacious humans and peace-loving inhabitants of the planet.
Yuri Leftkin isn't really a fan of anything extra-terrestrial.
Laika is a tragic character in the history of space exploration – a sacrifice to science on a one-way mission to space. She doesn’t die in this film though – she becomes a heroine in a completely different way.
 “The main theme of Laika is humankind’s relationship to animals, nature and the entire universe. It’s a topic that defies time and should be the absolute centre of discussion for our entire civilization.” (Aurel Klimt)
 “For over ten years, I've had the opportunity of seeing Aurel sweat blood on a daily basis. The amount of work, persistence and patience needed to pull this off, to get this far is absolutely incomprehensible. After ten years, he's nearly there and there's just a small step remaining.” (Prof. Jiří Kubíček, Prague's Film and TV School FAMU)
Aurel instructing Ham (the Chimp) how to move during the banana song.
It might escape the viewer at first, but making a stop-motion animated film with puppets, let alone one that spans the length of 90 minutes, is a truly painstaking ordeal. And since Klimt is a true follower of the proud and long-lasting tradition of Czech puppetry established by the likes of Jiří Trnka and Břetislav Pojar, he's not the one to take shortcuts.
Anatomy of Ham.
The fact that Laika is Czech Republic’s first properly stereoscopic animated film doesn’t exactly make things easier either. And it’s not just a gimmick.
Olivie, one of the animators, setting up the cave shot.
"The technology for this work is a classic animation of puppets with mechanical frames, in environments that are digitally recorded in 3D. It's a fluid connection between the advantages of hand-made animation and the possibilities of state-of-the-art digital technology with immediate control of animation and 3D effects. I feel that using 3D is rather apt for what's basically a work of science-fiction, especially during the scenes in space." (Aurel Klimt)
Stephen Chiodo 
One of the Chiodo Brothers, Stephen is responsible for special effects, clay modelling or animatronics for works like The Simpsons or Team America.
Giannalberto Bendazzi 
Giannalberto is an animation historian, prolific author, and professor. He is best known for his book Cartoons − 100 Years of Cinema Animation, a comprehensive guide through the history and development of animation worldwide.
                                                        Laika started off as a puppet play in a small theatre in Prague, Czech Republic, all the way back in 2002. It was a play meant for both children and their parents, who were still able to remember the absurdity and oppressive nature of the previous regime, which Klimt’s play has mocked relentlessly.
“It was amazing to be able to receive an immediate feedback from the audience, be able to hone the material over the course of many many repeats. The play was a live organism and a lot of the improvements on the original material can be seen in the film, even though it’s obviously a different format.” (Aurel Klimt)
Next year, Japanese TV station NHK produced a documentary on Břetislav Pojar and Aurel Klimt and has provided resources for Klimt to film an animated sequence of one of the scenes from the play. That’s now known as Laika’s pilot.
In the following years, Klimt has started working on making Laika into a three-part film. Working on an animated film with limited resources is difficult and therefore the progress was rather slow. It was first necessary to acquire and master the various technologies required for this project, for instance, Klimt has spent the entirety of 2009 mastering the science of stereography in order to make his use of the technology as good as it can possibly be.
The filming has started in 2010 and hasn’t stopped until now, when the last seconds of the material are being filmed. In terms of resources, that’s taken care of. The post-production though, is a different story. One that needs your help in order to have a happy ending.
If all goes well, Laika is set to premiere 3rd November 2017, the 60th anniversary of Laika’s flight into space.
€75.000 – Official soundtrack from the film & Bluray gets a 3D boost
Every backer receives a download of the official soundtrack from Laika composed and arranged by Miroslav Wanek and Marek Doubrava. Also, all Blurays will now come in two versions – 2D and 3D for all backers who bought any rewards featuring a Bluray of Laika.
€80.000 – Making of Laika + deleted / bonus scenes
We'll automatically add an extensive 'Making of Laika' download to each and every backer. Get ready for an intense behind-the-scenes look into the extensive production of the film. Also, we'll include a download of deleted / extra scenes from the film. 
€85.000 – A Director's commentary version of Laika 
We'll make an extra edition of Laika featuring Aurel Klimt's running commentary on all the parts of the film.
€90.000 – Aurel Klimt's previous films – digitally restored 
Once we get past this mark, we'll be able to fully digitize Aurel Klimt's Mashkin Kills Mashkin, The Fall and Bloody Hugo and make them available in HD to all backers who bought the 'Stream Laika in HD' reward and above.
 AUREL KLIMT (*1972) – screenwriter, director & producer 
Laika’s all-in-one director, producer and scriptwriter Aurel Klimt is an accomplished filmmaker. His mentors include the famous Břetislav Pojar (Lion and the Song, Balablok) or FAMU's Prof. Jiří Kubíček. His work transcends the label of a mere entertainment for children which is often attributed to animated films and it often includes scathing social commentary.
He is used to sitting on multiple chairs when it comes to his film or theatre work – in the past, he has taken the role of an executive producer, scriptwriter, editor, animator, director, scenographer or sometimes even a set designer. Since 1999, he has been teaching at Prague's Film and TV School FAMU where he also directed the Department of Animation between 2006 and 2015. In 2003, he established his Studio Zvon where has been working on Laika since 2007. Over the course of his creative career, Klimt has used a variety of styles and techniques in his award-winning films. For instance, his latest short film Glass Works combines CGI, motion capture and classic animation.
  MARTIN VELÍŠEK (*1963) – art direction, designer
Velíšek is an internationally renowned artist known for his ability to create compelling and bizarre worlds worlds full of absurd humour. Over the course of his life, he has made countless paintings, glass sculptures, posters and book illustrations. His work was part of exhibitions all over the world, including NYC, Seattle, Paris, Stockholm or Helsinki.
FRANTIŠEK LIPTÁK (*1962) – art direction, designer
František 'Fero' Lipták has spent the first part of his creative life working as a scenographer for pretty much every single theatre in the Czech Republic and Slovakia. His vast imagination has helped more than 90 plays come to life, many of which were awarded at international festivals. Since 1991, he focuses primarily on film, even though once in a while, he creates paintings that are highly sought-after both by private collectors and galleries from all over the world.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Aurel is a professional filmmaker. He's already got countless successful productions behind himself and the project is at an extremely advanced stage. Literally the only thing holding it back at the moment is the lack of funds for post-production, and to be honest, that's a relatively straightforward process compared to what the rest of the production was like.
 
The only thing which matters is reaching the goal. If we get there, we are positive we'll be able to deliver, and all of that thanks to you.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter
