updates.update_content:
Dear backers, tomorrow is our launch party to officially get Paul Ryan magazine out into the world! 
If you’re in Greenpoint, Brooklyn and want to drink some wine, laugh at some jokes and jabs at the expense of the weasel with the widow’s peak, and toast all the talent behind the magazine, come by! We’d love to see you! You can also pick up your print issue if you’ve pre-ordered one, or buy issues there. 
The event is at

We'll start shipping the week of the 6th, but you can get your issue early at the Paul Ryan launch party (and buy more!). They'll be readings, performances, wine, and the right amount of handshakes.
It's at the Kickstarter space in Greenpoint (58 Kent Street), and we'll be getting started around 7:30 pm. RSVP here.
Our Cover Proof Arrived...And It Looks Great!

updates.update_userinfo: With just hours to go, a sentimental message
updates.update_content:
Well holy heck, we've got just fourteen hours to put some clothes on this baby, lest it totter out into that cold February air unsheathed, feeling its way like all of us, naked, scared.
This time last year, James and I were nervously awaiting first drafts for The Neu Jorker—nervously because it was sort of a ludicrous, terrible idea, to make a cover-to-cover parody (of a magazine we actually love, a lot of people like, some people pretend to read, and the rest of the world thinks is full of retrospectives on PG Wodehouse) and we were relying on people to give us good words, and how often is six thousand of them spent on a woman becoming a horse really worth reading? Once, apparently.

updates.update_userinfo: Paul pumps us iron with just two days left
updates.update_content: With only two days left to raise two bag o' bones, we're releasing this never before clip of Paul Ryan-lookalike Branson Reese pointing at you, the reader. It's a spicy clip and not suitable for all viewers.

As January comes to a close, Paul Ryan and the rest of the GOP roots feverishly through their sock drawers, searching for any conviction or courage. Here at Paul Ryan Magazine HQ, we're prepping to bring the heat to the yes-men.
Here's another alternative cover, this in the style of

Today Paul Ryan turns 47 years old, which means he still has a decade or two to put all of what's happening in the past and declare himself a new man, and take the reins of the GOP once and for all.
But that's for later. Today he gathers with his family of good Christians, shoots some archery, ignores the rights of people who don't look like him, and eats the one slice of cake he allows himself a year.

While Paul Ryan struggles to keep his head above the deluge of soiled swamp water pouring out from 1600 Pennsylvania's front door, we're eager to present to you a new alt-Paul Ryan cover, this one in the style of People:

campaign.story:
Hi, my name is Michal, and I'm a lover of sandwiches. A day without a sandwich is, in my eyes, a day gone to waste. 
Inspiration for many haikus. Photo courtesy of Russ & Daughters.
As part of Kickstarter's make100 initiative, I'll be printing 100 limited-edition compilations of sandwich haikus. 
Haiku, as you may know, is a traditional form of Japanese poetry consisting of a 7-syllable line sandwiched by two 5-syllable lines. Each haiku in this compilation will serve as an homage to a specific sandwich, sandwich ingredient, sandwich concept, sandwich experience, sandwich home, or to sandwiches generally. Some haikus will be universally relatable while others will speak to an individual, deeply personal sandwich experience. All will exalt this perfect food.
The Book
This collection will be bound in a beautiful, collector-quality hardcover book and printed on high-quality paper. Each poem will be accompanied by a watercolor illustration drawn by friend and beloved coworker Katherine Pan ("kpan"). The illustration in the project image is an example of the type of artistry you can expect from the illustrations. 
A sample haiku from the collection:
Collaborators
Most of the haikus in the compilation will be written by me. However, some have been commissioned from friends, acquaintances, and enemies who either are sandwich lovers themselves or love a particular sandwich. 
Inspirational sandwich, watercolor form. Painting courtesy of Katherine Pan.
In Short
If you love sandwiches
or if you hate sandwiches
If you love haikus
or if you hate haikus
If you love watercolors
or if you hate watercolors
Back this project. 
Thank you.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I've never printed a book before, so it's possible I run into problems on that end. However, I've done significant research into printing costs and potential pitfalls before launching this project and am confident any snafus can be handled.

It's also possible that kpan will be too busy to illustrate each poem, in which case I'll attempt to illustrate the remaining poems myself, or find another capable illustrator.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

support.descp: one copy of the sandwich haikus collection

updates.update_content:
i got the proof and this book is REAL! see below for a sneak preview. 
PLAY

hey buds, a quick update for all of you before we head into a beautiful summer weekend here on the east coast.
first and foremost: happiest birthday wishes to my dear friend, colleague, and illustrator katherine pan. may your day be filled with light, laughter, and sandwiches.
second: the book has been sent to the printer! i'll be getting the proof early next week and will share that experience with all of you, perhaps through a live update if i feel like it.

my dear backers,
good news! after visiting a number of printers and refusing to settle for anything but the best for you, my friends, i've finalized the printing details and am ready to send the sandwich haikus to the press.
HOWEVER. i want to ensure that all of you have submitted your surveys and have the chance to submit your name for inclusion in the book (and also your address so that i can send you the book). you can find the survey by opening your preferred browser and navigating to www.kickstarter.com, where you will see a joyfully bright orange bar at the top, directing you not to some boring terms or privacy policy update but instead to your reward survey.

hello dear backers,
it's been a while since i've contacted you, and for that i apologize. i've been hard at work designing the layout of the sandwich book, and i'm happy to report that it's nearly complete. all that's left are a few last-minute tweaks borne of self doubt and the page(s) of the book that will be devoted to you, all the lovely people who supported me in this creative endeavor.

updates.update_userinfo: we did it! + kickstarter live TODAY at 4pm ET

updates.update_content:
hello dear backers!
we've entered the final stretch of the project, and i thought this would be a good time to pop in and say hello. it's been a low-key and sandwich-filled few weeks over here at sandwich haiku HQ, watching pledges roll in, drafting haikus, and being awestruck by kpan's watercolor skills. this weekend (like most weekends), i ate a delicious sandwich at murray's bagels: poppy seed bagel (untoasted), scallion cream cheese, irish smoked salmon, capers, & onions. yum. expect at least one haiku devoted to this sandwich.

mere moments ago, while i was eating a delicious tuna sandwich from littleneck outpost (the very same sandwich featured in the project video), the project hit and exceeded its funding goal. an omen? i'd say so.
THANK YOU to everyone who's backed and supported the project so far. there are still plenty of books left (i set the project goal lower than what it'll require to print 100 in case i needed to print fewer), so please keep spreading the word and the sandwich love.

campaign.story:
Hi, I'm Meg! I love art, always have, but haven't been giving it the priority in my life that I think it deserves. I'm trying to make more time for creativity in general - and sharing some of the prints I'm working on feels like a nice way to accomplish that, while getting more art out into the world. 
WHAT I'VE DONE + WHAT I'M HOPING TO DO: 
I'm pretty new to linocut printing (thanks Chase!) and am really digging it so far. I've done a couple of prints, mostly of flora and fauna, but am looking to take on something a little more complex.  
Some of my other prints
I've been working on a green sea turtle linocut (love the intricate patterns on their shells and fins) and am going to attempt to make a two-color print out of it. This means that instead of sitting against a white background, the turtle will be surrounded by a different color print, made from a separate sheet of carved and inked linoleum. 
The turtle itself is almost done. Here's how the cut has progressed: 
THE NEXT STEPS: 
Finish the carving process with a little more detailing on the shell and fins, then start working on designing and carving the background. 
Gather supplies. I'll need to buy another sheet or two of linoleum, inks, paper, envelopes, stamps, an additional roller and ink tray. 
Make the prints! The prints will be done with blue, green and turquoise inks on 8x10 printmaking paper.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I'm new to linocut printing! I've only done a few cuts with printing runs of 10 or less, so printing 100 of these turtles is going to be a new venture for me. It's possible the linoleum could get funky on me with so many pressing attempts. If that happens, I'd have to start from square one, as I don't believe linoleum has more than one life once it's gone belly up. 

I've also never done a duel-color print before. Uncharted waters.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
3D model used to create concept prototype.
Inspired by Kickstarter's Make 100 initiative, I felt it was a small and simple way to get into creating a project to finally produce my own product. 
For several years, I have worked with other companies such as Kidrobot under the artist name, Chuckboy to produce products like vinyl toys or t-shirts but I never had the opportunity to make my own self-produced item. 
Here, I am looking to create a cute but cool robot cat enamel pin in my own aesthetic. Enamel pins have made a resurgence recently and I've always wanted to make one.
I am a huge supporter of quality and presentation. The pins will be about 35mm wide and made of hard enamel with rubber backings and a backing card.
  Intended colors for pin.

campaign.story:
Upcycled silk “featherbuns” for a sustainable and colourful world 
The birds of the Amazon are among the most colourful in the world. Vibrant red, green, blue and yellow are their feathers; their radiant beauty treasured in Peru since thousands of years. Made into traditional headdresses, these feathers are a symbol of life in all its splendor.
Just like our “featherbuns”. Hair accessories, which are handmade from upcycled silk instead of real feathers. We believe that treating nature with respect is the only way forward today, no need to plunder resources. Let us appreciate the treasures that are right in front of us and make their beauty shine. 
Our one-of-a-kind featherbuns are knitted locally in Germany from new and unused silk scarves with minor imperfections and selected secondhand scarves that we spin into yarn. Order your featherbun or send in your own scarf for us to turn into your very personal hair accessory. You can also get your own DIY instructions from us. All the funds are used to pay our knitters a fair wage and to cover production costs.
We are ANNAMARIAANGELIKA, a new slow fashion label from Berlin, Germany, inspired by Peru and its people. And together with you, we would love to make the world a more colourful and sustainable place. Are you in? 
P.S.: Check out our styling tips for our featherbuns in the tutorial videos we post in the updates!
PLAY


„Featherbuns” aus Upcycling-Seide für eine nachhaltige und bunte Welt 
Die Vögel des Amazonas zählen zu den farbenprächtigsten der Welt. Leuchtend rot, grün, blau und gelb sind ihre Federn; ihre strahlende Schönheit wird seit tausenden von Jahren in Peru verehrt. Zu traditionellem Kopfschmuck verarbeitet, werden sie zum Symbol des Lebens in all seiner Pracht. 
Genau wie unsere „Featherbuns”. Das sind Haar-Accessoires, die aus upgecycelter Seide statt aus echten Federn von Hand gestrickt werden. Wir sind überzeugt, dass der einzige Weg in eine gute Zukunft der ist, unsere Natur mit Respekt zu behandeln. Ressourcen müssen nicht geplündert werden! Lasst uns stattdessen die Schönheit der unentdeckten Schätze sichtbar machen, die sich direkt vor unseren Augen befinden.
Unsere einzigartigen Featherbuns werden lokal in Deutschland aus neuen, unbenutzten Seidentüchern mit minimalen Produktionsfehlern und aus ausgesuchten Secondhand-Seidenschals gestrickt, die wir zu neuem Garn spinnen. Bestelle dein Featherbun bei uns, oder schicke ein eigenes Seidentuch ein, das wir für dich in ein individuelles Accessoire verwandeln. Du kannst auch eine DIY-Anleitung zum Selbermachen von uns bekommen.
Wir sind ANNAMARIAANGELIKA, ein neues Slow Fashion Label aus Berlin, das von Peru und seinen Menschen inspiriert ist. Zusammen mit dir möchten wir unsere Welt ein wenig bunter und nachhaltiger machen. Bist du dabei?
P.S.: Lass dir auch unsere Styling-Tipps für dein Featherbun im Video nicht entgehen!
The Collection
Our Featherbuns are unique hair accessories that add an individual touch to your everyday style. Made from high quality upcycled silk, these eye-catchers are as light as a feather and guarantee great wearing comfort. There are three different styles and nine bright colours for you to choose from.
Unsere Featherbuns sind einzigartige Haar-Accessoires, die deinem täglichen Look eine ganz besondere Note verleihen. Die federleichten Hingucker bestehen aus hochwertiger Seide und bieten besten Tragekomfort. Featherbuns gibt es in drei verschiedenen Styles und neun leuchtenden Farben für dich zur Auswahl.
Style: Classic Featherbun
Featherbuns are available in two lengths: 30 cm and 60 cm. Depending on the length of your hair, they are perfect for braids, buns and ponytails. Featherbuns are easily fastened with a beautiful glass-pearl bead-and-loop closure.
Featherbuns sind in zwei Längen ehältlich: 30 cm und 60 cm. Je nach Haarlänge sind sie ideal für Flechtfrisuren, Haarkränze, einen Dutt oder Pferdeschwanz. Sie können mit einem Schlaufenverschluss und einer Glasperle ganz einfach geöffnet oder geschlossen werden.
    Style: Featherbandeau
Featherbandeaus are headbands. They are stretchable and adapt well to all head sizes. They are 5-7 cm wide.
Featherbandeaus sind Stirnbänder. Sie sind elastisch und passen sich allen Kopfgrößen an. Sie haben eine Breite von 5 cm bis 7 cm.
   Style: Bridal Featherbun 
For your special day we created our Bridal Featherbun. It is particularly suited for elaborate wedding hairstyles because of its extra length of 120 cm. We also offer special bridal bundles, sets of six or twelve Featherbuns of your choice for you and your bridesmaids. 
Für den schönsten aller Tage haben wir das Bridal Featherbun kreiert. Mit seiner Überlänge von 120 cm eignet es sich besonders gut für aufwendige Hochzeitsfrisuren. Wir bieten sie auch im Set an, du erhältst sechs oder zwölf Featherbuns deiner Wahl für dich und deine Brautjungfern. 
DIY — Knit your own Featherbuns!
You're a keen knitter yourself or know someone who loves to try new knits and materials? Wonderful! We prepared detailed and illustrated DIY instructions to make your own Featherbuns which you can download at the end of the campaign.
Du strickst selbst gern oder kennst jemanden? Dann nichts wie los! Für alle Strickbegeisterten unter euch haben wir unseren DIY Reward vorbereitet. Du erhältst von uns eine detaillierte und illustrierte Strickanleitung für deine eigenen Featherbuns, die wir für dich als Download am Ende der Kampagne bereitstellen.
Inspiring Tutorial Videos 
We prepared several tutorial videos to show you how to easily use Featherbuns. All these videos will be published in secret backer updates during the campaign. By pleding to our campaign you get free access to all Featherbuns tutorial videos.
Wir haben verschiedene Video Tutorials vorbereitet in denen wir dir Styling Tipps und Tricks für unseren Featherbuns zeigen. Indem du unsere Kampagne unterstützt erhältst du automatisch alle Tutorials über unsere Kickstarter Updates per Email. 
The Art Print Reward
We would like to give you a special ANNAMARIAANGELIKA discovery for your walls: You will receive a Riso print of a delightful old tree from the national park of Huaraz, Peru. DIN A4 / 21 cm x 29,7 cm; monochromatic print in teal or carmin.
New Reward:  The Feather Brooch
We a re very happy to present you our new reward. It´s a hand knitted brooch also made of our vintage silk. It´s featherlight and a colourful eycatcher for your wardrobe. Available in 9 bright colours.
Wir haben einen neuen und ganz besonderen Reward für euch.
Unsere Feather Brooch. Die Brosche ist wie unsere Featherbuns handgemacht und aus Vintageseide gestrickt. Federleicht und farbenfroh ist sie der Eycatcher für euer Outfit. In 9 verschiedenen Farben erhältlich.
   Upcycling and Design Process
Featherbuns are inspired by traditional peruvian Featherworks. In collaboration with our knitter Rita, we developed an special upcycling knitting technique for silk scarfs. Each of our Featherbuns is manufactured with attention to detail and in careful manual work.
Featherbuns sind eine Hommage an traditionelle Federtextilien aus Peru. Gemeinsam mit unserer Strickerin Rita haben wir eine spezielle Technik entwickelt, die es uns ermöglicht, Seidentücher upzucyceln. Jedes unserer Haar-Accessoires wird mit viel Liebe zum Detail und in sorgfältiger Handarbeit von Strickerinnen in Deutschland gefertigt.
Upcycled colourful silk yarn
    Our lovley knitter Rita
   Available Featherbun Colours
As each vintage scarf is unique and the amount of scarfs we get from the vendors is often limited, we are only able to provide an approximation of the available colors. If you have any specific color requests do not hesitate to let us know and we will see what we can find for you!"
    Special thanks to:
Rita Keck, Juliane Erdmann, Denis Herzog, LVR, Denis Grabe and Irvandy Syafruddin.
          Merken
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We would love to produce a small series of our one-of-a-kind Featherbuns and can´t wait to share the DIY Instructions with you. For this, we need your preorders to pay our knitters a fair wage which values their handcraft skills. 

Some of you might already know as from our first successful Kickstarter Campaign in January 2016, which helped us gain a lot of valuable experience first time around. 

We come well prepared: The Featherbuns collection is finished, our prototypes are a success and we have reserved all the necessary materials for the production. If our crowdfunding campaign goes through successfully, nothing should stand in the way of the prompt delivery of your Featherbuns!

But never say never. And that is why we would like to promise you this: Should it really come to an unintentional delay in our delivery time, we'll make it up to you somehow. We'll go out of our way to find a solution together.

campaign.story:
Drawn Collections
For a few years now, I've been making drawings of imaginary objects collected into grids. They're abstract and improvised as I go but have elements of familiar forms. Are they undiscovered microorganisms? Prototypes of obsolete devices? Ideograms that didn't make the cut for the Rosetta Stone? Logos from failed startups? You be the judge. 
 They share a color palette and general vocabulary.
I like drawing these, in part, because it provides a nice break from the other creative work I do, which often involves soldering, programming and building big things that take a long time. It's nice to step away from the computer and just sit with a piece of paper, a brush, and ink.
But I do still like making things with computers — and when I started reading Programming Design Systems, Rune Madsen's excellent online guide to algorithmic graphic design, I decided it would be fun to make a generative version of these collection drawings.
Generated Collections
So, here are some generated collections, spat out by a program I made with p5.js. Each time the program runs, it picks a color palette and draws a grid of 100 objects using a menu of features (lines, polygons, etc), making randomized choices about combinations, placement, and other parameters along the way. No two collections will be the same but they all share a set of rules for their creation.
Examples of generated collections
  10x10" print
I've been working on this here and there for a few weeks and like the results so far. ~THERE'S SO MUCH MORE I'D LIKE TO DO THOUGH~ Right now there are 7 distinct features that it pulls from to create each object. I'd like there to be more like 30, so the generated objects approximate the visual diversity and complexity of their hand-drawn ancestors.
Examples of objects from generated collections
Rewards
I'm offering three different rewards:

Digital
You can get a unique 100-object collection generated just for you and emailed as a jpg. It will be not reproduced anywhere unless you choose to print it or post it online (both of which are fine).
Print
You can get a print of a unique 100-object generated collection generated just for you, printed on 10"x10" archival paper, and signed.
Drawing
You can get a collection hand-drawn with ink on 8.5" x 11" watercolor paper.
With all the rewards, you can indicate a general color preference, or just leave it up to chance/my imagination.
10x10" print


Inspiration
Like many humans, I love organized collections of things. I used to work in an audio archive and currently curate a popular website devoted to creative projects. ;)

Some of my favorite visual art involves observing and documenting related structures in the world, like Ernst Haeckel's Art Forms in Nature and Bernd and Hilla Becher's Typologies of Industrial Buildings.
Ernst Haeckel: Polycyttaria (1904), Bernd and Hilla Becher: Water Towers (1980-89)

I also enjoy a lot of work that applies the visual language and structure of collections to abstract or imaginary content. Examples include Mark Wilson's paintings that recall circuitboards or architectural plans and Luigi Serafini's exquisitely detailed field guide to a fantastical world of his own creation, Codex Seraphinianus.
Mark Wilson: Untitled (1973), Luigi Serafini: Codex Seraphinianus (1981)
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I'm still coding the collection generator to make it as visually interesting as possible. This could go on forever but I think that spending Feb adding new features and sending out collections in March will be just fine.

The test prints I've done look great and the process has been smooth. Still, there's always the possibility of delays. That's why I set the estimated delivery date in April even though I expect I'll be able to do it in March (shhh.. don't tell the rewards section).

I've been making these ink drawings for years. They take a while but I enjoy doing it.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hi all,

Things are chugging along with the Imaginary Collections. I've picked out paper for the drawings and will start on those soon. I've also continued to work on the program and now have it pulling from a dozen different geometric features, each with numerous possible variations. Stars, spirals, and radial arrangements of line segments are all recent additions. Next I'd like to play with different aspects of symmetry as parameters.

I plan to keep adding to program for the next couple of weeks and will send out surveys for jpegs and prints in mid March.

Here are three collections I generated this evening:

Hi Everyone,

I got some sample prints and they look great! Trying out a few different styles of paper with different textures.

campaign.story:
I want to draw a fist a day during Donald J. Trump's first 100 days in office. This is my form of peaceful protest. I hope it provides some sort of solace for me and for those out there who have felt discriminated against by his divisive campaign. I want to feel like I faced bigotry and hatred with love and creativity.
 I'll let the day decide for me how I draw the first. I may use pen, pencil, colored pencils, markers, paintbrush. I want this period of protest to allow me to explore new tools and means of expression.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The biggest risk here is not staying vigilant during this transition from a peaceful government to a mysterious one. As far as the project risks go, there's close to none. I just need to draw a hundred fists and mail them by the end of Trump's 100 days.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
It feels like world is prettyyyyyyyyyy effed up these days, so as a part of our Make 100 project, we wanted to create a little bright side for you to turn to, whenever things get a rough and you need to feel a bit better. 
Here's what we are doing: We're making a list of things that are great (as you can see in our video), and then we are going to whittle it down to 100 things and print them all on a card that you can keep tucked away somewhere, and turn to when you need it the most. Easy peasy & good vibes for all! 
How we will do it: Once the list is all done (it is probably almost done, we have a lot of great ideas as you can see in our video), we'll figure out how to get all 100 things on the back & front of a card (exact size TBD, but we are aiming for a wallet sized situation), and then print it using a service like moo.com or similar. Then we will put it in a really nice envelope, and either hand deliver or mail your card as soon as we get 'em. 
About us: We are Katie and Liz, and we are friends & colleagues. Hi!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Risks & Challenges include: having a hard time deciding on the top 100 greatest things we can think of & probably figuring out how to get it all onto a card, deciding what size card to use. But it'll be totally OK, promise!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
When you're queer, no one ever sits you down and says "This is our story." Sure, you hear snippets. Friends tell friends what they know, terrible movies provide some context, but you don't often get to share the experience of learning history together.
Geeks OUT wants to change that. We want to create a fun, inclusive, community-oriented way to invite friends, family, and anyone else to learn our story together.
Illustrations by Allison Kolarik: Greg Louganis, Nina Simone, Alison Bechdel, Audre Lorde
  Learning queer history doesn’t just help us remember we come from. It helps us think about where we want to go, and how to get there. As we enter uncertain times, creating a ritual that connects us, and teaches queer history feels more important than ever.
To make this happen, we're going to publish Serving Pride: The Handbook for Your Queer History Dinner Party.
In the model of the Passover Haggadah, Serving Pride will guide a group of dinner guests through a ritual meal where history is retold through readings, songs, games, recipes, and artwork.
Harvey Milk, Sally Ride, George Takei
  Serving Pride will tell tales of groups like the Daughters of Bilitis, who subverted gender norms and dared to create a proud queer community where before there had only been the closet.
We’ll yell chants from Stonewall, and sing songs about queers who rattled the establishment, fighting for the rights of the oppressed.
We’ll remember the drag ball culture of Harlem in the 1920s and queer trendsetters in the arts who redefined American music, literature, and fashion.
Larry Kramer, Keith Haring, Freddie Mercury
It will be will be fully illustrated by some of today's most amazing queer artists, and will contain original songs and recipes to make the evening as delicious and fun as it will be informative.
Some of the creators already signed on to contribute to Serving Pride include:
Allie Kolarik (Comic Book Afterlife)
C. Edwards (Abel Boddy)
Fyodor Pavlov (Bash Back)
Rogan Josh (modHero)
Tana Ford (Silk)
Will Varner (Buzzfeed Comics)
with more to be announced soon!
We want to make this book affordable for every queer who wants one, so in addition to printing a full-color version of the book, we’ll also be publishing a free printable PDF of the book, so you can be completely DIY about it if you like.
We want everyone to be able to get a copy of the book in time to enjoy it during Pride season 2017, starting in June.
Sylvia Rivera, Ellen Degeneres, Divine
 So what do we do need to do this? $9,500.
$4,500 to cover printing and shipping costs 
$2,000 for artwork 
$1,500 to hire a researcher 
$1000 to hire a copy editor
$500 for the Kickstarter fees
Obviously, no dinner party can cover the entire American Queer experience, but we'll be building a bibliography of our sources, so it'll be easy to look up more information about the parts of the dinner that interest you most.
We hope the Serving Pride dinner party will become a colorful new tradition in every queer household, where we can all raise a glass to those who have fought for our freedoms, knowing that their work may not be finished, but their legacies continue to inspire us.
Please help fund Serving Pride!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Time is the biggest factor here, with book printing costs being what they are, getting a completed, color filled book in time for June 2017 is going to be hard.

We've got the right team in place and have good contacts for book publishing, so while it will be tight, we believe we can overcome this easily.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hey Fam! 
A quick note before the break. the completed proof is in the hands of our talented copy editor/proof reader. 
We're on track to have this completed and in your hands by early 2018! 
Thank you for all the support and we're sorry about the delays!

updates.update_userinfo: Survey's Sent! Books Delivered in May!
updates.update_content:
Hi folx! It's been a hot minute since our last update. The book is nearly completely almost 100% totally very finished. We want Serving Pride to be as good as it can be, so rushing it to the finish line wasn't an option for us, and a few aspects are just taking longer than anticipated. Thank you for being patient and bearing with us as we wrap up the book.
The holiday season is not the best time to try and print, ship, or promote a new independent book, and we want Serving Pride's debut to be as strong as possible. That's why we are planning the release for early 2018, marking a full year from our Kickstarter launch. The timeline isn't what we'd originally planned, but the nature of the project necessitated some some flexibility, and in the end, the extra time was important to the quality of the finished product. We hate to make you wait any longer, but we don't think you'll be disappointed once the book is in your hands!

updates.update_userinfo: FINAL PROOF- Off to Printer on Monday
updates.update_content:
Hey everyone! 
We're working on the last bits of serving pride as we speak with a print deadline of October 9th! 
We're so excited for you to see the final product, and thank you to everyone for helping us with the beta!

HAPPY PRIDE!! 
After months of hard work, we are SO EXCITED to reveal the Serving Pride Preview Edition! 
This edition has no, recipes, references, or any supplemental material. BUT it does have everything you’ll need to THROW A TESTER PARTY! 
We are very eager to get your feedback. Please, please, please download the book and start planning your queer history dinner party!

campaign.story:
**UPDATE** We have reached minimum viable stupidity - please help us reach our stretch goals.
The Stupid Shit No One Needs and Terrible Ideas Hackathon is a free one-day event where participants are asked to make projects that have no value whatsoever.
The Stupid Hackathon was founded in New York in 2013 and since has spread to over 300000 cities across the world. 2017 marks our fourth anniversary and we're raising funds to make it the stupidest event of the year. The bar is high this year. Will we rise to the challenge?
Specifically, we're looking for $$$ to cover food, prizes, and materials for our February 25th NYC event.
Guardian reporter, Arwa Mahdawi wrote this about the 2016 Stupid Hackathon:
"I am watching some of the best minds of my generation build dildos, disrupt solid foods and monetize children...
Organized by creative technologists Sam Lavigne and Amelia Winger-Bearskin, the Stupid Hackathon satirizes a strain of first-world “innovation” that sees funding pour into gimmicks such as “smart cups”, connected devices that tell you how much water to drink."
The Stupid Hackathon is always free and open to all. You don't even need to know technical skills like coding or soldering to participate, just have a few terrible ideas.
PRESS: read about our 2016 hackathon via Motherboard, The Guardian and Popular Mechanics.
Stupid projects from previous years
Soylent Dick
  3Cheese Printer
  Non-Ad-Blocker: Blocks everything that isn't an ad.
  Assistive Pizza Eating Device
  1.4mb USB Drive
  Meat Circuitry
  Twerk To Work: Electricity generation device
  Tinder For Babies
Check out more past projects at: http://stupidhackathon.com
Tweet at us @stupidhackathon
Email us at stupid@stupidhackathon.com
Rewards:
Our Stupid T-Shirt is on Sale from $120 to $25!
This year's T-Shirt!
In the past, Stupid Hackathon stickers were free for everyone, but this year we are experimenting with "trickle-down" economics and trickling in general, so if you decide to finance us through Kickstarter we'll give you a sticker as a kickback.
We sent a few early ones out to our biggest fan, Mark Zuckerberg, founder of FaceMash:
He likes it. (NOT TO SCALE)
 Kickstarter Credits: Audio by Cassie Tarakajian and Devin Curry // Videography and growth hacking by Nicole He // Graphic by Ziv Schneider

campaign.story:
Faces Are Hard to Do: Make 100
Hi, I'm Susan McClellan. I live in the wilds of Vermont's Northeast Kingdom. I’m a book designer and magazine art director. Currently I art direct Vermont Life Magazine.
My new passion is oil painting. I've been working at it and improving over the past 10 years.
So far I’ve shown and sold paintings in VT galleries and art shows — mostly still lifes and landscapes. 
  Throughout my time painting, I've largely avoided rendering faces, because Faces ARE Hard to Do. When painting faces I can tense up and lose confidence, and the results are sometimes more humorous than intended:
(with apologies to Willa and Daniel)
Actually, I was trying to make this guy look bad.
Clearly I need practice, and Kickstarter's Make 100 seems like a good way to get that. So I’m here to find up to 100 faces — strangers, acquaintances, friends, family, everyone is invited! — to use in my quest to paint better and more interesting likenesses.
Here’s how it’ll work:
Back my project for $20 or more and I’ll make a painting of your face (see the reward tiers for all the options). Once the project is over, I’ll send out a survey requesting several photos of the face you’d like me to paint. It could be of you, your kid, your significant other, your grandfather, your favorite actor or actress, your best friend, your dog or cat or bird ... anything really. Once I receive your image options, I’ll pick the one that's most intriguing and get to work on a one-of-a-kind painting that, if anything, will be a conversation starter in your home. :)
I'll do my best to make a captivating likeness, but you should know that I'm not trying to paint like Vermeer (no danger) or Norman Rockwell. I’m more inspired by impressionistic painters like Matisse, van Gogh and Munch. I aspire to create paintings that are expressive and spontaneous, working to capture the essence of a subject without slavishly representing reality. 
Here’s an example of a face I painted recently, next to the photograph it's based on.
(Photo by Michael Sipe)
So, join my quest. Be part of this little experiment. If I get enough faces, perhaps I'll hang them in an art show. If that happens, all my backers will be invited to the opening!

Hi Everyone, and thanks so much for backing my project — I continue to be surprised and humbled each day as new backers join my quest to paint up to 100 faces! I'm excited to get started with the paintings, and as soon as the campaign ends, I'll be sending out a request for your photos. So you might want to start looking for a few great images to send me. The best photos to paint from are candid (selfies are usually not good for this), expressive, highly detailed, and have interesting or dramatic lighting (natural light is best).
In the meantime, here's what I painted yesterday: a face of another sort, for the Womens' March on New York City, where I marched yesterday with my daughter.

campaign.story:
The Beauty of Southwest Idaho
     In my non-photographic life I’m a counselor. My role as a counselor is to help people explore their world and discover their authentic self. This search for authenticity is part of my being, and it’s also part of my photography. Rather than just taking pictures, I want my images, my editing and my processing to match my personality. I work to reveal my character through the images I create. As an authentic photographer, I believe the moments of the world are worth capturing and sharing with others. And I believe I have a unique perspective worth sharing, as do all photographers. For me, that unique perspective is one of minimalism and simplicity. As I’ve simplified my life, I’ve also simplified my photography. 
      This series of images is of the Owyhee Mountains in southwest Idaho. Although the mountain range is long, and big - as mountains are - I find myself drawn to the ‘small,’ hidden details. The hazy summer air reveals hints of ridges adding depth to the quiet scene. Conversion to monochrome enhances the simplicity of the scene, allowing my imagination to travel through the mysterious mountains.
     As a supporter of this project, you will receive a set of five prints, one of each image below. Each image is printed on high-quality textured paper with a matte finish, measuring 5" x 5". These prints are ready to frame or to send as a card.
     Each set of prints will be numbered and signed. And since this is a "Make 100" project there will be only 100 sets created and numbered.
The Images

campaign.story:
Thanks for your interest in YogaCows! I think Cows doing Yoga is hilarious and I thought you might too!
YogaCows started after some Saturday-morning yoga stretches with my kids. We started playing with their farm animals, laughing as I put the toys in different yoga poses. Soon enough we had a whole YogaFarm set up.
I thought about these photos and poses for over a year. I'm ready to assemble my favorite twelve poses into a beautiful 2018 Calendar. (Note, the images you see here are not the final artworks).
With a different YogaCow pose each month, this spiral-bound 11x17 Calendar of black-and-white photos will make you laugh every day. And it's Press-Printed in the USA, so you know it's quality!
This is my first Kickstarter. I was drawn in by their Make100 campaign. With your help, this project is totally achievable.
You can receive a limited-edition 2018 YogaCow calendar of your very own! Please back my YogaCow campaign before it's too late!

campaign.story:
Project circulum'C
This series is a meditation on colour. Through this series I explored how colour evolves and transforms. The piece as a whole investigates the evolution of colour and the transformation of a circle into a sphere, When broken down the individual segments undergo a transformation in visual form and presence, giving them their own voice and story. It is a look at how objects can work in a singular form yet come together in a harmony whose sum is greater than the value of it’s parts.
Project ciculum'C: 100 circular iterations of colour
  100 Individual Prints of Circulum'C
100 Pieces
The circulum’C project is part of the 100 Pieces art philosophy that I have been developing for the last 5 years. The philosophy is an examination of fragmented beauty and how their simplistic and isolated existence holds a multitude of meanings.
The individual pieces come together to transform them from a singular entity to becoming a larger piece of art that is greater than the sum of its parts.
Until now I have explored this philosophy through fashion and textile media but the Kickstarter make/100 movement for 2017 inspired me to create the circulum’C graphic art series.
The idea that one piece of art can be spread across the globe with a fragmented existence yet still be connected fascinates me. The fact that something can be singular yet multi dimensional intrigues me. 100 pieces is about exploring global connectivity.
       The Product
You will receive a One-of-a-Kind 20” x 20” (508mm x 508 mm) Fine Art Giclée Print on Canson Aquarelle Rag museum grade 310 g.s.m., 100% cotton fine art paper. This Canson paper is one of the best in the industry. It is used globally in art galleries and museums and gives the artwork a beautiful warmth and superlative texture.
You will also receive a signed certificate of authenticity that will show where in the Project circulum’C series your piece fits. It will be hand marked 1/1 to show that your piece is One-of-a-Kind.
Please keep in mind that the frames are not included and are for demonstration purposes only. (The beauty of 100 Pieces is putting your own stamp on the piece. What better way to achieve this, than how you choose to frame and display it).
     The Artist
I’ve worked with different art media over the years from watercolours, oils, ceramic to textiles, photography and typography. But throughout all of this my undying obsession with colour and basic geometric shapes has never left me. These elements continue to appear across all my work. The best way to catch a glimpse of my aesthetic is to have a look at my visual journal on Instagram.
To keep up to date on the circulum’C project or to if you’d like to follow the 100 Pieces philosophy and its upcoming projects check out the website.

campaign.story:
WE BELIEVE ART HAS THE POWER TO WAKE PEOPLE UP.  
Eight years ago, the artist Shepard Fairey made the iconic image that captured a period of HOPE in America. Today we are in a very different moment, one that requires new images that reject the hate, fear, and open racism that were normalized during the 2016 presidential campaign. So on Inauguration Day, We the People will flood Washington, DC with NEW symbols of hope.
This art has been already been commissioned by the Amplifier Foundation. Some of the greatest activist artists working today, including Shepard, Ernesto Yerena, and Jessica Sabogal, have collaborated with photographers to create a series of images that capture the shared humanity of our diverse America.
Now the tricky part: printing and distributing these images on a massive scale in time for Inauguration. 
Much of Washington will be locked down on Inauguration Day, and in some areas there will be severe restrictions on signs and banners.  But we've figured out a hack.  It's called the newspaper!  On January 20th, if this campaign succeeds, we're going to take out full-page ads in the Washington Post with these images, so that people across the capitol and across the country will be able to carry them into the streets, hang them in windows, or paste them on walls.
Every dollar you put into this campaign will buy six ads printed and distributed for us.
Amplifier will also distribute these images as large placards throughout DC at Metro stops, out the back of moving vans, at drop spots to be announced in the coming week via our social media feeds, and, on January 19, as free downloads for you to print and share as you like.
And for every donation over $5 we will even send a postcard of the art of your choosing to the incoming President after he takes office! (Stay tuned for the text we will use!)  
This art is meant to spark a conversation, and after January 20, our work will continue. What does WE THE PEOPLE—these three famous words in the preamble to the Constitution—mean in the 21st century? Over the next several months, Amplifier will partner with organizations, schools, and everyday families to create spaces across the county, in both red states and blue, where we can speak, listen, and share our answers. Watch for updates on this as the campaign funds and moves into the world!
WHO ARE WE?
SHEPARD FAIREY is one of the most accomplished street artists in the world, and creator and founder of Obey Clothing and Obey Giant, first becoming known for his "Andre The Giant has a Posse" sticker campaign while at the Rhode Island School of Design. He became widely known during the 2008 presidential election for his Barak Obama "Hope" poster. 
JESSICA SABOGAL is a first generation Colombian American muralist. Her art serves as a haven, a tribute, a creative outlet of adoration and exaltation for women with stories often untold. Her pieces possess a vision of female identity that is revolutionary and powerful, brave and beautiful. Most recently she has created a visual campaign entitled, “Women Are Perfect” which attempts to spread this simple but necessary notion worldwide.
ERNESTO YERENA is an artist living in Los Angeles.  His art brings political concerns to light with subject matter that depicts cultural icons, rebels and everyday people voicing their stance against oppression. While Yerena identifies as Chicano he also strongly identifies as Native/Indigenous to this continent which is often seen in his work. Highly recognized for his activism, Yerena is the founder and curator of the Alto Arizona Art campaign (2010) as well as a founding member of the We Are Human campaign (2009).
THE AMPLIFIER FOUNDATION:  Our non-profit is dedicated to amplifying the voices of grassroots movements through art and community engagement. We do this by funding collaborations between those movements and contemporary artists so that their messages can reach a wider audience. Our goal is to flip artists into activists and observers into participants.  
Our work has supported Criminal Justice Reform projects with Cut50.org, Environmental campaigns working with Indigenous groups against the KXL pipeline and in defense of Treaty Rights in the Black Hills, and we have, just this week, commissioned, and started printing and distributing the majority of the art for the Women's March on Washington as an official partner.  
WHY KICKSTARTER?
We are here to find partners as much as funding.  When this message is heard we want them to know it comes direct from the people.  Our goal is 10,000 backers in this Kickstarter and ten times that many participants after Inauguration day. 
THE REWARDS:
 STAY TUNED FOR PHASE 2!
___________________________________________
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
No matter what, we have the ability to get tens of thousands of pieces of this art printed to distribute for free in public. We also have guarantees from the silkscreen and offset printers that our product can be made in a timely manner. There is a very, very small chance the Washington Post could reject our ad at the last minute, though we have been talking to their ad department for some time and they know what we are running. If that were to happen, we would buy ad space in other DC papers that day, and we would continue to spread the art beyond Inauguration Day via billboards, bus-shelter ads, etc.
___________________________________________________________________

updates.update_content:
Friends!
It’s been too long! I wanted to get you a final update!
With the exception of those who have not sent us shipping addresses yet, all We The People rewards have officially shipped! In addition, in under three months, you enabled us to give away over a million free prints and downloads in 205 countries, distribute 245,000 print ads in the New York Times, Washington Post, and USA Today, and begin to reshape the national narrative. Our work is only beginning, and we look forward to partnering with you to flip even more artists into activists and observers into participants.

Friends!
Every day truckloads of lithographs, screen prints, and sticker packs are leaving our Los Angeles Hub!
We have 30,000 total packages going out in the next 3 weeks, but rest assured yours is coming soon!!! It may even arrive today!
Please help us continue to spread these messages by sharing photos of where you hang them with the tag #amplifierfoundation!

Friends!!

Thank you so much for your patience on receiving your artwork and for all the support you have shown us over the last month. It is because of each of you we can move forward and continue to create free artwork for these social movements and for all the people marching for our rights!  

This email is to update you on the status of your orders, which are expected to arrive in March.

Friends!   
We hope you've seen the fruits of this campaign, but if you haven't we have updates!  Ive been meaning to send this for days but have been overwhelmed by literally thousands of calls and emails and am just now digging myself out!  
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Friends! 
We have so many pieces of news to share with you!
Last night the campaign you contributed to surpassed the one million dollar mark. This is much more than we could have ever dreamed of, but our goals remain the same: To make a statement of our values on January 20th and then to take that statement and carry it beyond the inauguration into the world. Over the coming year, Amplifier will partner with organizations, schools, and everyday Americans to create spaces across the county, in both red states and blue, where we can share a dialogue about the diverse and dignified America we want our children to inherit.

campaign.story:
Hello, I'm Zack Applewhite, I am a hopeless romantic, a poet, and would love to write you a poem.
The Basics
You pledge at least $1.
I will send you a message WITHIN 24 HOURS asking for information about your poem. (Who's it for? Themes? Features to highlight?  Is there anything special you want me to include? etc) 
I start working on your poem
I send it to you over the internet by Valentine's day
That's it. 
The Story
In my last project I wrote about a variety of topics for a variety of people and had a blast!!. It was challenging and inspiring to write about topics I never would have written about before AND I WANT TO DO IT AGIAN!!. 
Then I saw a few very interesting projects that inspired me. The first being 100 Flower Paintings by Katherine Pan. After seeing this project and others like it I decided I wanted to join in the fun.
I decided I was going to write 100 personalized love poems in about 30 days. It's weird, it's spontaneous, and I can't wait to get started!!!
So if you have a boyfriend, girlfriend, spouse, partner, long lost love, someone who doesn't notice you but occupies your every thought, beloved goldfish, or just want to feel the love yourself, back this project and bring a little more romance into your life.
 Things to keep in mind
Kickstarter is all or nothing. If the $100 goal is not reached, then unfortunately the project will not happen.
You can pledge more than $1. There is absolutely no reason to do this other than to help the project reach it's goal.
There are only 100 spots and no more. 100 poems is only barely doable, anything more and people will either get less quality poems or not get them on time.
If you miss out on this campaign: I am sorry you missed out but I have no plans to open up more spots. However, if you follow my Kickstarter profile you will be notified when I launch my next project, so that you don't miss out agian
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Conveying an emotion as strong as love is not easy to do, and because each of these poems will be personalized to reflect 100 individuals feelings/situations on the complicated matter of love, this project will be especially difficult. (I look forward to this challenge)

Worst case scenario: If I can't get you your poem by Valentine's Day I will refund your pledge and send you a personal apology.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

It's Time to Say Goodbye. I would like to thank each and every one of you for supporting me and sharing with me. You have contributed to my growth as a poet and a person. The vast array of laughs, fears, hopes, dreams, memories, and so much more will stick with me forever.

This will be my biggest and final poetry based campaign. A massive collection everything I have to offer and everything WE have done together.

All the best,

campaign.story:
I want to paint your cat's portrait! 
Hello, my name is Mr Let's Paint (John Kilduff) and I have a new painting series that I want to start and your cat can play an important role in it!
In my last Kickstarter (In My Dreams Art Residency), I painted Moth's cat as one of the rewards. His cat is an orange cat and it sort of looks like my orange cat (see pictures below). I posted the picture on Facebook and people thought the painting was a portrait of my orange cat and I had to say no...it's Moth's orange cat. And than I thought...I know at least 5 people that have orange cats..why not make a large painting with all the orange cats that I know?...how about a large painting of all the black cats that I know and all the cow cats that I know, etc, etc. 
This is where you come in... with your support and cat, I can make these large paintings. The paintings will be 4 feet by 5 feet or larger. I plan to make three large paintings for starters....one of only orange cats, one of black cats, and one of cow cats. Based on the response from you...I may add or change the groupings...maybe a mixed group too? 
For you reward...I will be painting 100- 8" x 10" oil portraits of your cats. I than will include your cat in my larger paintings! All cats will be put in the larger paintings! ...(no matter what they look like)
Now, if you would like a painting of your dog, your loved one, pet fish, etc....I can also paint that for you. Maybe if I get enough requests for dog portraits...I might do a large painting of dogs too!
Thanks so much for your interest and support!
Mr Let's Paint
Please check out my past Kickstarters and my website letspainttv.com for more information about me.
Moth with his cat and cat's portrait

campaign.story:
Collaborative fiction, especially fiction inspired by real people and their stories and worldviews, has always fascinated me. This project allows me to explore other people's stories, while also challenging myself to expand my boundaries in 2017. Coming up with ideas on my own is relatively easy when contrasted with using other people's prompts. 
This project was inspired by the authors who wrote on street corners with typewriters. When patrons stopped, the author wrote them a story based on a prompt and then gave them the story. Tell Me a Story is an homage to that in Kickstarter format. 
 Flash fiction is one of my favorite things to write. It’s clean, it’s simple, and it’s a challenge to keep it the correct length. My flash fiction tends to be 200-300 words. This is because I hand-write the stories in journals and then transcribe them later (as an editing pass). Keeping each story a page long allows me to use the paper itself to help judge how much longer I have to wrap up the story while also seeing how much room I have to to make the story the best it can be. 
Fiction is always better when other people are involved. This is why I would like you, as a backer and a reader, to give me a prompt for a story. 
2017 is the year I want to challenge myself. With your help, I can make this happen.
I’m excited to see what we can come up with!
  When not fighting crime or tinkering with Tarot spreads, Vivian Caethe writes weird fiction, science fiction, fantasy, quirky nonfiction and everything in between. She has more than twenty five short fiction publishing credits to her name and is working on more. She has an MFA in Creative Writing from Regis University and is a member of the Editorial Freelancer’s Association. She also drinks copious amounts of tea. While doing all these things, she lives in Colorado with her super genius cat. 
This project will fund the creation of a limited edition hardcover and an ebook to accompany it. The funding will be used to pay for: 
Writing the stories 
Proofing 
Cover 
Layout 
ebook formatting 
Book printing 
Fulfillment (Shipping will be extra, depending on your location. $5 for domestic and $15 for international.
$1 – Encouragement – for this you will receive my gratitude and your name in the acknowledgements.
$7 – Enthusiasm – this gets you an ebook copy of the book after it’s finished as well as your name in the acknowledgements.
$30 – Inspiration – this gets you the opportunity to provide one prompt for the book, the page the story was written on in the journal, and one of the 100 copies of the limited edition hardcover book itself once it’s finished. 
A survey will be sent to all backers at the Inspiration level after the Kickstarter is completed, and these backers will be requested to provide a genre, a prompt, and (if wanted) why this prompt was chosen. Prompts should be no more than five words, but they can be anything you can think of. Places, names, objects, tastes, or whatever you would like most to read.
That being said, no erotica, rape, incest, or violence against women or minorities will be allowed and backers who select topics in these categories will be disqualified with no refund. 
Backers may choose to have their name on the same page as the story they inspired. The book will be a limited edition and only 100 hardcover copies will be printed. The copies will be signed and numbered. Backers at this level will also have their name in the acknowledgements.
January – Kickstarter commences 
February – Kickstarter ends 
August – Deadline for stories written 
September – Book proofed, formatted, and cover complete 
October – Books ordered 
November – Books shipped to backers, ebook links sent 
Art by Owl Quest Creative
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
It is no small feat to write 100 flash fiction stories. This project, with prompts from my backers, will be an added challenge. However, I have done challenges like this before, completing a flash fiction story a day for a year in 2012. Those flash fiction pieces later became “Handwritten,” a short story collection that I self published in 2013. 

As this is my third Kickstarter, I have experience with the process and getting rewards to backers. My other two kickstarters (The Writer's Block Tarot and Humans Wanted) have also taught me how to work under deadlines and communicate well with backers. I am currently fulfilling and shipping one project and am in process with another one. The growing experience from completing these projects will allow me to learn more that I can apply to this one. 

After working for WordFire press and self-publishing my own books, I have significant experience publishing books and have a dedicated team of freelance people to help me complete the cover, layout, and proofing tasks. In the past I have had no problems using LightningSource, the POD company that I use for hardcovers.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
First off, thank you all so much for your early support. I really appreciate it :) 
It's an interesting experience doing this Kickstarter. This is the first one that doesn't have anything to offer other than my own writing. It's a little frightening and a little daunting, to be honest. With the Writer's Block Tarot, I had the cool concept, plus the art and a thing that people could use to improve themselves and their craft. With Humans Wanted, I had the names of my authors and the awesome idea provided by Iztarshi to set the stage for success. 
But with Tell Me a Story, it's just me and what I can offer. It's daunting and also a little freeing. This is a challenge that I have to take upon myself and only me. This will stand or fail on the strength of my writing and my ability to stick to deadlines. I have faith in myself and know I can do it. Now I just need to convince 100 other people to have faith in me as well.

campaign.story:
The 100th Bird
  This is a very special bird, the last in a series of 100 watercolor paintings. He was created with a single paintbrush and Indigo pigment.
 But why did I paint 100 birds?
I’ll tell you the story:
Earlier this year, I lost everything in a fire. There was a freak accident and most of my possessions went up in flames. I was basically left with a backpack, a laptop, and a little paint set.
Early Painting After the Fire
I was confused, lost. I moved to New York City, because that’s what you do, right?
So, I was sleeping on my friend’s couch, looking on Craigslist, and I saw an amazingly cheap sublet for an art studio. It wasn’t a whole studio, it was an eighth of a studio, actually, but something told me to go see it. And after I saw it, something told me to rent it.
Mind you, I had never had my own studio before, nor did I know what I would do with it.
But if you have a studio, you show up, right?
It looks like I had a plan, but I really didn't.
So I showed up.  I showed up and I started to paint.
I painted because that’s all that I had left. At first my paintings were pretty rough. (See below.)
This is confusion, in watercolor form.
 I decided that I needed to pick a subject and master it. I didn’t know what to pick at first, so I just picked ‘Blue’. Maybe because that’s how I felt.
I couldn't get over my love for Indigo.
 The Indigo pigment I paint with is ancient and universal, and there was something in the color that felt like magic.
If birds wore saddle shoes, this bird would.
  I painted birds, because they are a symbol of hope. I committed to making a hundred paintings. Mainly because it made me look like I had a "plan".
As people started reacting to my work I gained more confidence. I had a show in Brooklyn, and sold out!
The first flock of birds
For the first time in my life, people were saying “Thank you,” as they bought my work. Which is ironic, because this was the first time I was actually doing something for no one else but me.
He looks a little dazed, kinda like me.
Slowly, things got better.
I started letting the paint tell me what to do. I stopped struggling so much. I kept painting, bird by bird.
A New Day, A New Bird
When I was confused, my birds were confused. When I was happy, my birds were happy.
This is me before coffee.
  This is me after coffee.
The very last bird, the 100th bird, flew out of my brush. Once he was painted, I knew he was the last in the series. I am thankful for all the things these paintings have taught me, bird by bird.
The 100th Bird
I had a show to commemorate all these birds and sold out again!  I am amazed by the support from people around me. 
Birds of a Feather
All of the birds from this series have found homes, but I wanted to offer this final bird to you, in case you are in need of a friend.
To me he is a symbol of what showing up every day can do for us.  As the yogis say, "Practice and all is coming."
He told me he likes you.
  The 100th Bird is a symbol of hope for me, and I hope he will be for you, too.
You don’t always need a plan, you just need to try. 
Wishing you Peace, Love, and Birdsong,
Alex
This is the Fine Art Print, measuring 8 by 10 inches.
 Specifics:
This Kickstarter is for a Limited Edition of The 100th Bird. Each giclée print is in full-color, of the highest quality, made on deluxe cotton rag paper, and printed at a renowned printing house in Brooklyn. The final piece is cut to size by hand, and measures 8 by 10 inches. Each bird is individually signed and dated with a #2 pencil by the artist.
Each print will be sealed in plastic for safety and mailed in a flat-pack.
Goodies!
All Love Birds and Super Awesome People will receive a FREE gift, the very popular Indigo Kitty Magnet.  No need to feed or water, and excellent for all metal surfaces!
Indigo Kitty Magnet!!
 All Super Foxy People will receive a FREE gift, the very charismatic Fox Sticker. Made of high-quality, durable vinyl, he would love to live on your laptop or anywhere else you can think to stick his fine self.
A Fantastic Mr. Fox.
 The first 100 backers will receive this custom temporary Bird Tattoo!  Designed by yours truly, it will make you look really, really cool.
How cool is this???
 UPDATES:
Thanks to everyone's support, I now will have the funds to release birds into the world!  These additional birds represent states of existence very familiar to me: "Sleepy" and "After Coffee".  Each bird print 8 x 10 inches, and on the same paper as "The 100th Bird".
The 100th Bird is slightly more awake than Sleepy.
  Caffeine gives him wings.

campaign.story:
My desire as an artist has always been to create my best work and have it be accessible to a wide range of people. My working process has favored consistent themes explored over multiple paintings. Because of this, I have enjoyed making paintings on a smaller scale and having them be more cost effective for collectors. 100 Trees is a natural echo of that process.
Sample Tree Painting in its Frame
   My subject matter for these paintings will be a single, monumental tree, painted in water media on a 5x7 panel. The finished paintings will be framed in an elegant black frame that hangs easily on a wall or sits as comfortably on a table. 
Ready to Work
 Starting in April, on a rolling release, I will upload finished paintings as they are produced and backers will have a chance to claim them on a first come, first served basis. If a lot of people express interest in a particular painting, I will produce variations of that theme and the resulting series of 100 paintings will become a shifting vision of artistic growth. Each piece will be ultimately unique, bold and one of a kind. Backers will also have the chance to follow along with blog posts, process videos and other tidbits as this series unfolds.
Sample Webpage for Choosing Paintings and Bonus Material
 In addition, when the 100 paintings are finished, I will ask backers to vote for their favorite piece of the entire group and the winning painting will be turned into a high quality, limited edition, hand signed and numbered giclee print. This 5x7 print will be available in both an unframed and framed variety.
Sample Print
 Thank you for your support and I am incredibly excited to see how this project unfolds.
Sample 3 Framed Paintings
Timetable:
February - Start painting with expectation of approximately 6-8 paintings per week. Begin uploading pieces with periodic reminders for backers to check available works. Begin shipping paintings to backers as they are claimed.
May - With all the work finished, tally votes for the favorite painting.
June - Deliver prints as final reward
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Making art entails balancing the many time constraining variables of practical life while working away feverishly at the thing you most love to do.

The challenge for this project (and for all art projects) is finding enough time to produce the work at hand. 

For 100 Trees, I able to accomplish this for two reasons; first, I have made a number of similar tree paintings in the past so I am very familiar with the particulars of this process and two; I have time every day dedicated for making art – it has been and continues to be my full time job!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Homeworlds 1-15
Stretch Goals Update--
For every extra $100 we reach over the $500 goal, I will add a new Homeworlds card to the postcard set(This will add a page to the zine and a poster choice as well), with the max number of postcards and pages being 50...
Altered States
If we reach $3500 by the end of the campaign (for a total of 50 postcard designs) we will unlock "Altered States".  Each postcard "location" will be given a name based on warping a name of a state in the union into an alien version itself in the form of an anagram. For example: Alaska would now be Kalsaa, Arizona would now be Zaronia. This name will be printed on the message side and not the art side of the postcard. 
New Limited Edition Poster Set Reward--
Check out the new rewards tier that includes all 11 x 17 posters (regardless of how many there end up being) for $100(limited at 25 sets) Since every $100 we reach over the $500 goal adds a new postcard/poster design, if you choose this reward, BAM! You just added a new design to the set!
Since postcard sets are already limited, this tier will not include the postcard set. Altered States names will be printed on the reverse side of the posters if we reach that goal.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Homeworlds is a postcard tour through 20(+) alien landscapes in collage. All images used come from a single source, Yoshikazu Shirakawa’s landscape photography book Eternal America. Shirakawa's book is full of breath-taking and unconventional views of the American west. I’m digitally remixing these bold images to create new and imaginary vistas that speak to the strangeness (and estrangement) of the American political climate.
Homeworlds 1-9
Here the first 9 postcards. I will be creating and posting the remaining 11 throughout the month of January.
Homeworlds 10-15
The Image Source
Shirakawa's Eternal America
I picked up Eternal America at a thrift store several months ago.  Shirakawa's (mostly) aerial photography captures the landscape as if surveying an unseen world for the first time, rediscovering the mystery in well-trod territory. I’ve been looking for a reason to re-purpose these images since I found them.
Postcards
I’m inspired by American postcards from the 30’s and 40’s --more specifically, the images made for the National Parks Service by the Works in Progress Administration, and “Linen” postcards, (popular postcards from the time that featured boldly colorized and manipulated photos printed on textured paper.).
WPA Poster - Zion National Park
  Vintage "Linen" Postcard - Lake Erie
Postcards have a long tradition of mixing the real and the fantastic to capture the allure of far flung locales. As I started working on these images, it became clear that I was using them to telegraph a sense of frustration and dread.  These are postcards from hostile territory. 
Make 100
Make 100 offers a scope in which I can produce this entire project from start to finish. I have my own printer to print all postcards, posters, and books. I’ve managed a much larger Kickstarter project before. No Biggie. By the way, meet my buddy Ricoh. He’ll be doing the heavy lifting.
"Ricoh" the Ricoh Color2000
Kickstarter
As I’ve found using Kickstarter before, it’s a way to connect with people all over the world. I want to share this project with you whether you find yourself in your own hostile homeworld, or with any luck, in some more hospitable climate.
Rewards
In the  spirit of Make 100 I'll keep it simple...
$5  Mailed Thank You Postcard
You get the postcard of your choice, mailed to your door with a special thank you message. 
$15  Homeworlds Zine
This is a 20 page 5.5 X 8.5 color zine with each of the postcard designs on it's own page.
Homeworlds Zine
  Homeworlds Zine
$25 Homeworlds Limited Edition Postcard Set w/ Poster
20- 4 X 6 postcards, one of each design in a handmade  card stock sleeve, and one 11 x 17 poster of your choice.  (Sleeve also printed with your poster choice image)
Homeworlds Postcard Set
  $100 Homeworlds Limited Edition 11" x 17" Poster Set-
You get all 20(+) designs on a set of 11" x 17" posters in a hand made 12" X 18" card stock sleeve printed with the poster image of your choice(similar to the postcard sleeve shown above.) 
Homeworlds #1-15 11x17 Posters

updates.update_content: Workin' hard this week to put together postcard sets, then on to posters and zines.  Hoping to get stuff in the mail by the end of next week.  *crosses fingers*
Please refer to this chart when filling out the survey for your rewards...

We made it $1120 past the $500 goal.  That $1100 gets you 11 more postcards on top of the original 20 for a total of 31!  31 Pages in the zine, and 31 poster and postcard choices as well.  Big thanks to everyone who backed.  
I finished the 31st design last night.  So 31 designs finished in the 31 days of January.  Below are the remaining designs.  And here's all the designs on my wall dwarfing my messy desk and my confused cat.

One day left!   Looks like we got a little last minute boost.  Big thanks to Jenn of Egg-Centennial for including Homeworlds in her Happenings newsletter:

campaign.story:
Hi - I'm Jenn de la Vega, but I should really change my last name to de la Vegg. One of my favorite things to do on Instagram is pop egg yolks. You'll see my fork, chop stick, carrot or breadstick slowly creep into frame before piercing the bulbous yolk. 
And what happens next is the oddly sexual flow of yellow, a spurt of what once was shining and bright. It's extremely satisfying to watch. 
Click here to learn more about my food photography on the Kickstarter blog.
Many of my videos are filmed in the comfort of my own home and I've been the only one enjoying a year of luscious eggs.
I want to cook 100 eggs and film 100 consecutive egg yolk pops! 
Here's where you come in! You can eat, decorate, pop and name yours. We will have an aerial camera set up on a table where we will document each pop. We'll edit them together in a glorious montage of yolk porn. 
What are our expenses?
120 eggs (extra in case of breakage!)
Egg cooking: butter, oil
Popping implements: forks, chopsticks, asparagus, grissini, bread, carrots
Toppings: tomato sauce, pesto, cheese, spices, bacon & more (will be posted fully in a backer update).
For eating: plates, napkins, breakfast drinks
Cameraperson & editing 
If we reach our goal, every additional $25 will go toward a new topping option for everyone. And refreshments, like mimosas! I will take suggestions if you tweet me @Randwiches.
If you are unable to make the February 11th date, please change your pledge to the AQUAFABA tier to show your support. Each of the tiers has exactly 25 slots for people who can make it. 
Who: You & me & an egg.
What: An epic day of egg eats.
Where: Brooklyn, NY
When: Saturday, February 11th. A backer survey will go out to confirm a time slot with you. 
Why: For the love of eggs.
How: Together!
You will check in at your designated time and will meet with me when your name is called. While you wait you can meet other egg enthusiasts and browse the menu of toppings. I'll cook your egg, top it and send you off to the photo booth. You'll place your egg down. We'll document the name of your egg, recipe and your own personal pop. 
After we're all done, we'll share all the GIFs and epic yolk porn video for all to enjoy.
*Don't live in Brooklyn? I'd love to bring an egg popping party to your town in 2017. Email randwiches@gmail.com to see how we can make it happen.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
There is no way I will perfectly cook 100 eggs, we'll have to budget for extra eggs.

I have my New York City food handler's license, so you can be sure that I will take your food safety as seriously as possible. I'm also obligated to say consuming raw or undercooked meats, poultry, seafood, shellfish, or eggs may increase your risk of foodborne illness. If you've got a sensitive immune system, it might be best to sit this out.

Toppings will be first-come, first served. If we run out, we run out. But I'll make sure there are a lot of options for you to choose from.

campaign.story:
In "Invisible Cities," Italo Calvino imagined fantastic lands explored by Marco Polo. Worlds where the customs and laws of nature that we know do not apply.
In "Invisible Courts," I will imagine fantastic realities for the NBA. Universes where up is down, left is right, the midrange jumper is the most efficient shot in the game, and Benny the Bull is an all-seeing god.
"Invisible Courts" will explore the NBA from new angles. 
What if an NBA team played in a high school gym? 
What would the draft lottery look like in another dimension? 
What if Isaiah Thomas lives as a giant in a Gulliver's Travels world of his creation?
As a diehard fan of the NBA, these are the questions I often think about. And if you back this project, for better or worse you will too.
 “With cities, it is as with dreams: everything imaginable can be dreamed, but even the most unexpected dream is a rebus that conceals a desire or, its reverse, a fear. Cities, like dreams, are made of desires and fears, even if the thread of their discourse is secret, their rules are absurd, their perspectives deceitful, and everything conceals something else.” — Italo Calvino, "Invisible Cities"
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The biggest challenge is having the discipline to write, design, and edit this piece. But this project is part of a New Year's Resolution to practice my creativity more, so I'm game for the challenge.

I decided not to make any physical copies as I worried that extra effort of printing and mailing would deter me. But I plan to include instructions for printing your own physical copy.

Finally, I am not Italo Calvino. So those expecting fine literature, I apologize in advance.

updates.update_content:
Good morning Invisible Courts backers.
There's a new post up on our fine publication.
The inspiration was the question: What could end the NBA? What event could transpire that would make the league stop?
After a lot of careful consideration, the answer was obvious: The NBA will end when all the players quit to become venture capitalists.

Tonight I posted a new story on Invisible Courts. You can read it here.
One day I had the thought: surely there must be an NBA player who intentionally tries to play for bad teams so as to make their summer vacation as long as possible.
I decided to research this, looking for which players had made the most money while never making the NBA playoffs. There I found Jason Thompson, an anonymous player for the Sacramento Kings who made $33 million playing for nine years, making the playoffs only once in his final season. Right after, he retired from the NBA.
The facts mentioned in the story, including his being waived by the Warriors during their 73-win season, are true. This is an exploration of the mentality behind these career choices.

Hello backers —
I promised a March delivery of the zine, however not all the stories will be done in the next week. As that work finishes, I'm going to share some of the stories collected as Project Updates. Here's the first one. It should give you a sense of the kind of mood these stories are looking to create. I hope you enjoy.
Going for 100
