Congrats Stacey! Can't wait to see where this project goes! You rock!
I hope all your gosh darn American pie dreams come true. You are a treat and a treasure.
LOVE LOVE LOVE! Slaying the pie game all across America!
Your pies are beautiful! Can't wait to see the rest of the states!

campaign.story:
THANK YOU BACKERS FOR HELPING US REACH OUR GOAL!!!
WE NOW HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO APPLY ADDITIONAL BACKER PLEDGES TOWARDS OUR STRETCH GOALS. 
PLEDGES UP TO $39,000 WILL GO TOWARDS COVERING KICKSTARTER FEES & STRIPE PAYMENT SERVICE FEES THAT ARE TAKEN OUT OF INITIAL PLEDGE GOAL AMOUNT.
PLEDGES ABOVE $39,000 WILL GO TOWARDS PRE-PRODUCTION EXPENSES (PUPPET AND ANIMATION/SPECIAL EFFECTS RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT).
TOO LOUD A THANK YOU!
"I felt beautiful and holy for having the courage to hold on to my sanity after all I'd seen and had been through, body and soul, in too loud a solitude..."
Too Loud a Solitude Film Poster, Art By Yevgenia Nayberg
Our team has been committed to bringing Czech writer Bohumil Hrabal's beloved novella Too Loud a Solitude to the screen since 2004. In 2007, we completed a 17-minute excerpted version of the feature script, starring Paul Giamatti as the voice of Hanta. The film short played nationally and internationally in the Handmade Puppet Dreams program and in 2009 was awarded a Citation Of Excellence by the Union Internationale de la Marionette (UNIMA-USA). Our team is now beginning work to turn the book into a full-length feature film, again featuring Paul Giamatti.
Paul Giamatti (Photo © Jeff Neumann 2016)
WHY WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT 
The $35,000 we are seeking (about $31,500 after Kickstarter fees) will cover puppet design, armature creation, motion exploration, character development, costume design, and visual effects.  It will also cover extending the book option (which is secured), operation expenses, and legal fees.
We are in the beginning stage of raising funds for the entire feature with both US and European financing and production partners. Anything our founders contribute above the campaign goal will greatly assist in our stretch campaign of getting the entire film made. Donors seeking a tax deduction can contribute outside the campaign under our 501(c)3 umbrella, and can contact us directly at genevieve@tooloudasolitude.com
We hope to have puppet design, assembly, and research & development of overall design completed by the end of spring 2017, with principal photography following in early summer and post-production going into fall.
Too Loud a Solitude Book Necklace, $150 Incentive
SYNOPSIS, BACKGROUND, STYLISTIC APPROACH
“Lost in my dreams, I somehow cross at the traffic signals, bumping into street lamps or people, yet moving onward, exuding fumes of beer and grime, yet smiling, because my briefcase is full of books and that very night I expect them to tell me things about myself I don't know." 
Too Loud a Solitude is the fantastical story of a book crusher named Hanta whose job is to destroy the precious works of literature he loves so much.  The story of Hanta's quest to save the world of books and literature from destruction is often cited as the most beloved of Hrabal’s books.
Too Loud a Solitude has a global fan base and an active community of support has emerged for our feature film project.  The book has been translated into 37 languages and sold over 70,000 copies of Michael Henry Heim's English translation alone.
Bohumil Hrabal wrote the novella as an unsentimental account of what happened to him during the Russian occupation of Czechoslovakia during the 40’s and 50’s.  Many of Hrabal’s books were banned by the Russian regime and other great books by many authors were physically destroyed, an act Hrabal characterizes in Too Loud a Solitude as “crimes against humanity."  
The magic of Hrabal's lyrical and tragicomic writing came from the courage to remain open to what he called “the Flood of Sparkling Experience,” an openness to seeing life in its fullest capacity and a commitment to giving even the most common of characters the right to a poetic portrayal of their thoughts and lives. 
We are very excited about the stylistic approach to the film, which will incorporate not just the puppets but rotoscoping, cell animation, compositing with historical footage, photographs and special effects. Our aim is to create a moving and thought-provoking film by combining analog and digital techniques in a patchwork of styles past and present, all in service of Hrabal's exquisite imagination.
Director Genevieve Anderson Will Discuss Puppets With You Via Skype
DIRECTOR'S STATEMENT
I made my first short film, Boxed, after a harrowing incident that happened to me while traveling in a remote village in Mexico where I might have lost my life.  Making the film was a way of making sense of what had happened, and imbued the puppet figure with a vitality that hinged on life and death. This was interesting for me in light of how the puppet figure naturally bridges life and death - one minute it is inert and lifeless, but when a puppeteer puts their hands on it, the form suddenly comes to life.  The practice of making and working with puppets took on a kind of sanctity that I had never encountered in all of my years working with real actors.
After Boxed won a jury award at the Berlin Film Festival, I made my second and most personal short film, Sunlight (2000), a dystopian vision of a future void of natural light. My third short, Ola’s box of clovers, about my wonderful, cantankerous grandmother, followed in 2004 and played at festivals worldwide, won several awards, and was broadcast on IFC and ARTE France.  
Hanta, The Film's Narrator, Will Tweet His Thanks To You
Soon after, an acquaintance who had traveled to Prague gave me a copy of Too Loud a Solitude and said, “This would make great material for one of your puppet films.” I opened the book and read from the first page:
“For thirty-five years now I’ve been in wastepaper, and it’s my love story...I am a jug filled with water both magic and plain; I have only to lean over and a stream of beautiful thoughts flows out of me...”
This and the book's many other poetic sentences made a strong impression on me.  I felt that Hrabal's language was perfectly suited to an interpretation with puppets and animation because it demands a vision that comes from a place of imagination and dream - a place untethered to the ordinary world. When I received a grant from the Rockefeller Media Artist Foundation, I immediately began development work with Kelly Miller (Producer) and Alex MacInnis (Writer and Editor) to turn the book into a movie.
Too Loud a Solitude Desk Caddy, $200 Incentive Reward
We started our journey with a trip to Prague, where we met many of Hrabal’s friends and found inspiration in the beauty of the city, its people, art, and culture. In the years since, there have been moments when we thought we were crazy for continuing to push the project forward, but we honestly believe it is the enduring power of the book that has brought our project to a place where it can finally become a feature film. 
This is a significant step for me as a director because this will be my first feature film. I have learned a tremendous amount over the years making my short films, including the 17-minute version of Too Loud a Solitude, and am thrilled to finally be at this step with the project. It's been a truly amazing journey - filled with joy and despair and doubt and incredible grace - and we are excited to invite you along for this next momentous stage of the journey!
PRODUCTION TEAM
Genevieve Anderson, Director (Boxed, Sunlight, ola’s box of clovers).  Awards in Berlin, Seattle, Rhode Island, Chicago.  Rockefeller Media Artist Grant Recipient. Producer for Bill Viola)
Steve Gaub, Producer (Beauty and the Beast, Unbroken, Oblivion, Tron: Legacy)
Kelly Miller, Producer (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, Y Tu Mama Tambien, Forgiven)
Frank Rehak, Producer and Historical Consultant (School of Photographic Studies, Prague)
Evan Jacobs, Visual Effects (Captain America, Ant Man, Avengers, Alice in Wonderland)
Alex MacInnis, Writer (This American Life, Down to the Bone)
Greg Bachar, Literary Advisor & Outreach Coordinator (Author of Curiosisosity, The Amusement Park Of The Mind.  Executive Producer, Elstree 1976)
Yevgenia Nayberg, Costume and Graphic Designer (National School of Arts, www.nayberg.org)
MJ Mynarski, Composer (A Deadly Adoption, Lost Boy, Darkness Before the Dawn, Emmy-winner)
Eli Presser, Lead Puppet Designer (Basil Twist, Kevin McTurk, Genevieve Anderson)
Too Loud A Solitude Film Site
Facebook
Twitter
Genevieve Anderson
Too Loud a Solitude Desk Caddy, $200 Incentive Reward
"My education has been so unwitting I can't quite tell which of my thoughts come from me and which from my books, but that's how I've stayed attuned to myself and the world around me for the past thirty-five years.  Because when I read, I don't really read; I pop a beautiful sentence into my mouth and suck it like a fruit drop, or I sip it like a liqueur until the thought dissolves in me like alcohol, infusing brain and heart and coursing on through the veins to the root of each blood vessel." --Bohumil Hrabal, Too Loud a Solitude
Too Loud a Solitude Storyboard Incentive Reward. Artist: Christo Stamboliev
  Too Loud a Solitude Costume Design Sketch Incentive Reward. Artist: Yevgenia Nayberg
  Too Loud a Solitude Set Design Sketch Incentive Reward. Artist: David Max
KCRW'S MICHAEL SILVERBLATT ON TOO LOUD A SOLITUDE
  Director Genevieve Anderson
  Puppet Set Prague Street Scene
  Hanta from Too Loud a Solitude
  Too Loud a Solitude Book Necklace, $150 Incentive
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
A film's production process is only as strong as the creative team involved with its production. I have full confidence in my team and look forward to working with them on the next phase of our project after it is successfully funded, thanks to you!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

support.title: Too loud a thank you
support.descp: Too loud a thank you for supporting our project! Too Loud a Solitude author Bohumil Hrabal will toast you from his celestial throne!

support.title: Your name on our web site
support.descp: We'll add your name to the acknowledgments page of our web site.

support.title: Tweet from a puppet. Twuppet? Tweepet?
support.descp: We don't know whether to call it a "twuppet" or a "tweepet," but Hanta, the star puppet and main character of Too Loud a Solitude, will tweet you his thanks. Follow us on Twitter and include your Twitter name with your pledge. Includes acknowledgment on our web site.

support.title: A postcard in the mail from the director
support.descp: Director Genevieve Anderson will thank you personally with a handwritten note on a Too Loud a Solitude film postcard, featuring art by Yevgenia Nayberg. Includes acknowledgment on our web site.

support.title: Too Loud a Solitude original soundtrack
support.descp: Download of original soundtrack by Emmy award winning composer MJ Mynarski. Twelve beautiful compositions commissioned for our 2007 Too Loud a Solitude film short, plus bonus film trailer track. Includes acknowledgment on our web site.

support.title: Film short download & script
support.descp: Download of our seventeen minute Too Loud a Solitude film short, made in 2007, starring Paul Giamatti as the voice of Hanta. Includes film short script by Alex MacInnis for you to see how we adapted the book. Acknowledgment on our web site.

support.title: Home Czech & Slovak arts festival
support.descp: Producer Frank Rehak's essential Czech & Slovak literature, film, and music recommendations with commentary about their relationship to Czech & Slovak cultural history. Includes Spotify music playlist, recommended reading & viewing lists, Frank's commentary, and acknowledgment on our web site.

support.title: Too Loud a Solitude book and bookmark
support.descp: A copy of Bohumil Hrabal's novella with a Too Loud a Solitude film bookmark, featuring art by Yevgenia Nayberg. Includes acknowledgment on our web site.

support.title: All things Too Loud a Solitude
support.descp: Film short download & script. Download of original Too Loud a Solitude soundtrack by Emmy award winning composer MJ Mynarski. Digital storyboard and design e-portfolio (a selection of storyboards by Christo Stamboliev, costume design sketches by Yevgenia Nayberg, and set design sketches we used to make our 2007 film short). Also includes home Czech & Slovak arts festival, thank you Tweet from a puppet, and acknowledgment on our web site.

support.title: Signed puppet films DVD
support.descp: DVD of our 2007 seventeen minute Too Loud a Solitude film short, starring Paul Giamatti as the voice of Hanta, signed by Director Genevieve Anderson, and Anderson's other puppet films: Boxed (12 min., 1998), Sunlight (17 min., 2000), and Ola's Box Of Clovers (10 min., 2004). Includes acknowledgment on our web site.

support.title: Prague calendar and souvenirs
support.descp: 2017 Prague calendar of beautiful original photos of the city by Olga Mendel, signed, and a selection of souvenir items personally collected for you from Prague by our team: a U Zlateho Tygra coaster from Bohumil Hrabal's favorite pub, a bag of Haslerky candies (named after Karel Hasler, renowned Czech singer and actor), a Bohumil Hrabal Postrizinske beer bottle label, and a folding postcard of 3D Prague Castle and Charles Bridge. Also includes acknowledgment on our web site.

support.title: Literature and translation book duo
support.descp: A copy of Bohumil Hrabal's novella Too Loud a Solitude, film bookmark, and The Man Between: Michael Henry Heim and a Life In Translation, by Esther Allen, Sean Cotter & Russell Scott Valentino, Editors, about the life and work of Hrabal's renowned translator, whose translation allows us to enjoy the book today. Includes acknowledgment on our web site.

support.title: Book signed by translator Paul Wilson
support.descp: We will send you a copy of Bohumil Hrabal's short story collection Mr. Kafka: And Other Tales From The Time Of The Cult (New Directions Books), signed by translator Paul Wilson. Mr. Wilson also translated writings of Czech President Vaclav Havel and was a singer with legendary rock band The Plastic People Of The Universe. Also includes acknowledgment on our web site.

support.title: Reception at Czech Center New York
support.descp: Join us for a special evening at the Czech Center New York on Thursday, December 1 at 7:00 p.m. for a viewing of the Too Loud a Solitude film short followed by discussion with Director Genevieve Anderson and Producer Kelly Miller. Airfare, accommodations, and ground transportation not included. The Czech Center is located at 321 E. 73rd Street at the Bohemian National Hall (between 1st and 2nd Avenue). Includes refreshments, film swag bag and acknowledgment on our web site.

support.title: Too Loud a Solitude book necklace
support.descp: Exclusive handmade Too Loud a Solitude book necklace designed specially for our donors. Made from reclaimed materials by artists Peg and Awl, the necklace features a handmade book inscribed with Too Loud a Solitude and Bohumil Hrabal on the front cover and a quote from the book inside (see photo). Wear a book and support the film! Also includes acknowledgment on our web site.

support.title: Too Loud a Solitude desk caddy
support.descp: We'll send you a handmade Too Loud a Solitude desk caddy inscribed specially for our donors with a quote from the book (see photos). Made by artists Peg and Awl from reclaimed Heart Pine finished with tung oil. 6″ long by 3″ wide by 4″ tall. Includes acknowledgment on our web site.

support.title: Visit the L.A. puppet fabrication studio
support.descp: For those curious about the puppet arts and puppet design, we'll arrange for you to visit the fabrication studio in Los Angeles where we will be designing and making the puppets for Too Loud a Solitude. Director Genevieve Anderson will discuss the puppet making process and the film. Airfare, accommodations, and ground transportation not included. Includes acknowledgment on our web site.

support.title: Storyboard and design print portfolio
support.descp: Print portfolio of beautiful storyboards and design sketches we used to make the 17 minute film short in 2007. A selection of storyboards by Christo Stamboliev, costume design sketches by Yevgenia Nayberg, and set design sketches, presented in an elegantly-wrapped folder. Includes download of the 2007 film short and acknowledgment on our web site.

support.title: Bohumil Hrabal's Czech New Wave
support.descp: For the Czech New Wave film lover, we'll send you the film Closely Watched Trains, based on Bohumil Hrabal's novel of the same name, and the four DVD collection Pearls Of The Czech New Wave, which includes Pearls Of The Deep, a five part anthology of films based on a selection of Bohumil Hrabal's short stories. Comes with a viewer's guide penned by our resident expert on all things Czech, Producer Frank Rehak, who will enhance your viewing experience with valuable insights into the Czech New Wave. Also includes film short download & script, home Czech & Slovak arts festival, a postcard in the mail from the director, and acknowledgment on our web site. Due to DVD region coding, this item ships only to U.S. and Canada.

support.title: New York lunch with director & film team
support.descp: We'll take you out for lunch and discussion about the film, puppets, and Bohumil Hrabal at Bohemian Hall & Beer Garden, located at the Upper East Side's Bohemian National Hall in New York City. Includes Czech, Slovak, & grill favorites from the menu (we're prohibited from offering alcohol as an incentive item; airfare, accommodations, ground transportation not included). Includes film swag bag and acknowledgment on our web site. Lunch is at 12 noon on Saturday December 3, 29-19 24th Avenue, Astoria, New York.

support.title: NY dinner with director & film team
support.descp: We'll take you out for dinner and discussion about the film, puppets, and Bohumil Hrabal at Bohemian Spirit, located in the Upper East Side's Bohemian National Hall in New York City (airfare, accommodations, ground transportation not included). Also includes film swag bag and acknowledgment on our web site. Dinner is at 6 p.m. on Friday December 2.

support.title: Skype with Director Genevieve Anderson
support.descp: Curious to know what it's like to make movies with puppets? We'll arrange for you to have a 30 minute conversation via Skype with Director Genevieve Anderson about her films, puppets, and Too Loud a Solitude. She'll even give you a private tour of her studio! Includes download of the 2007 film short and acknowledgment on our web site.

support.title: Prague guided tour
support.descp: For donors who would like to experience Bohumil Hrabal's Prague, we can't fly you there but we can offer you a guided 3 day/2 night tour of the city by our Producer Frank Rehak. Frank is an expert on Prague and a former Fulbright Teaching Fellow at the Czech Film & Foto Academy in Prague. Discover all the best the city has to offer: galleries and concerts, great restaurants, secret museums, interesting artists, architecture and theater. Visit Hrabal's favorite pub, U Zlateho Tygra, and other Hrabal spots the writer frequented and that appear in his work. Talks about Czech culture included. Airfare, accommodations, ground transportation, cost of meals and event admission not included, but Frank will help arrange your itinerary and lodgings. Must be available to travel late September/early October 2017.

support.title: A puppet YOU in the film!
support.descp: Director Genevieve Anderson will make a puppet in your likeness to be used as one of the supporting or background characters in the film. And when production of the film is complete, you get to keep the puppet! We'll send you images of your puppet being fabricated and an invite to see it being made in person if you're in the Los Angeles area (does not include airfare or accommodations). Also includes acknowledgment on our web site.

support.title: Too loud an angel supporter
support.descp: For our angel supporters, the "Bohumil Hrabundle:" our eternal thanks and gratitude, acknowledgment on our web site, tweet from a puppet, postcard in the mail, film short download & script, home Czech & Slovak arts festival, signed puppet films DVD, literature and translation book duo, book signed by translator Paul Wilson, film bookmarks, Too Loud a Solitude book necklace & desk caddy, storyboard & design print portfolio lovingly placed inside a handmade box in the shape of a book with Too Loud a Solitude inscribed on the cover. Also includes Bohumil Hrabal's Czech New Wave and an invitation to your choice of visit to L.A. puppet fabrication studio or reception at Czech Center NY or NY lunch with production team or NY dinner with production team. To top things off, in honor of your generous contribution, we will include a one of a kind miniature prop used in our 2007 film short and a personal thank you from Hanta, the narrator of Too Loud a Solitude.

support.title: Literary journal
support.descp: Receive a year of poetry, fiction, essays, and interviews from our friends and fellow lovers of Hrabal and literature at Conduit Literary Magazine, "The Only Magazine That Risks Annihilation." Includes acknowledgment on our web site. Only 2 available.

support.title: Book reviews & poetry chapbooks
support.descp: In the spirit of Hanta, the main character of Too Loud a Solitude whose love of books propels the story forward, our friends at Rain Taxi Review Of Books will send you a year of the magazine and two of their artfully-made poetry chapbooks: Clatters, by French writer Henri Droguet, and The Road To Camden, by Dutch writer Kees 't Hart. Includes acknowledgment on our web site. Only 5 available.

updates.update_content:
Dear Too Loud A Solitude Backers,
This update is long overdue so I thank you all for your patience and understanding. The time between completing our Kickstarter in late 2016 and now has been very active and productive.
As most of you know, we traveled to the Czech Republic in February of 2017 and secured a producing partner at In Film in Prague, along with several post production partners.

Happy December, TLAS Backers!
It has been a full and productive year for Too Loud A Solitude, and on behalf of our entire team, I want to thank you all for helping us accomplish so much. In addition to gaining a producing partner with In Film in the Czech Republic, as well as making alliances with several enthusiastic vendors, we have made great progress with our new puppet development.
Eli Presser has done tremendous work getting Hanta into a larger, more capable form, recently bringing on digital sculptor and fabricator Brent Johnson (who made the lead puppet in ). After numerous discussions about the fine line between keeping the handmade aesthetic while improving the puppet's acting abilities on film, we decided to wade into the waters of 3D printing internal mechanisms that will hopefully bring our puppets into their fullest potential.

updates.update_userinfo: Genevieve Anderson Live From Tubac & Too Loud A Solitude On Social Media
updates.update_content:
Director Genevieve Anderson will give a talk about Too Loud A Solitude on Thursday, October 26 at the Tubac Center of the Arts (5-7:00 p.m. Tubac, Arizona time).
If you're in the area or know anyone who might be interested, please consider attending and/or sharing the event information:
Arts Speak: Genevieve Anderson -- Too Loud A Solitude (Event Info)

Hello Backers,
Given the recent sadness, anger, and confusion, I wanted to share this piece I wrote back in February when I was really contemplating what Too Loud a Solitude means in our current sociopolitical climate. I did not intend to post it other than on my personal website, but I read it today and felt compelled to share it. I am not critiquing anyone's political beliefs, rather wanting to look from the broadest perspective I can muster, and offer something that feels like hope. It is long, unedited, and imperfect, so please forgive that. If you're able to read it, my sincerest desire is that it speaks to the place in you, as in me, that believes in us.

Hello Backers,
Here are a couple of pictures and videos from my visit last month to Eli's home studio, where he has been working on the new prototype for Hanta. We've increased the scale from 12" to 18", and we are working on adding simple mechanics for mouth, eye, and hand movement. It's been a challenging process, but super interesting! Everything that Eli is doing comes from long conversations around what makes the movement most alive while keeping the raw and handmade feel of the puppet. I am very excited about the developments and can't wait to show you all what we come up with!

Hello TLAS Backers!
Just a quick update to let those of you who ordered TLAS books that they have been sent. If you ordered one and it hasn't arrived by end of week please let me know.
Paul Wilson books forthcoming.
Czech and Slovak Arts Festival  and All Things TLAS backers - this has been a little more difficult than we imagined to compile, but it is almost finished, so sit tight, it's got some great items on it!

campaign.story:
I'm Brandon Bird, and I'm an artist living in Los Angeles. Driving around Southern California, I've often seen people use their vehicle as a memorial to a loved one who has passed away. Usually, this is a decal in the rear window, noting the person's date of birth and date of death. But there's also a much larger tradition of using the entire car as a surface for self-expression (here's a good article about one of the prime examples of lowrider art). I started thinking about the kind of art car I'd like to make. Who would I want the pay tribute to? The choice was obvious.
I would like to raise the money to:
1) Buy a used sedan (something big and American-made from the early 2000s, like a Crown Vic),
2) Hire some of Southern California's talented airbrush muralists, pinstripers, and body paint experts,
(example of work by @oscargraphics)
3) Work with those artists turn the sedan into a custom work of art dedicated to the late actor Jerry Orbach.
Q: But why Jerry Orbach?
A: Jerry Orbach has long functioned as a source of personal and artistic inspiration. A muse, if you will. 
Many years ago, I found myself in a rut--I was about to be unemployed, and the most exciting thing in my life were "Law & Order" marathons on TNT. But in Jerry Orbach's character of Detective Lennie Briscoe, I found a spark. Here was a man made weary by the world, who nonetheless persevered. His acerbic wit and hangdog attitude couldn't mask a natural warmth and kindness. I got off the couch, and put together an art show. I made a "Law & Order" coloring book, which was the first thing I ever did that became a viral hit, and that has snowballed into an entire career making ridiculous pop art. I owe a lot of good things in my life to Jerry Orbach.
A bemused Jerry Orbach is shown the "Law & Order" coloring book on "Late Night w/ Conan O'Brien."
His own life was also filled with kindness. He wrote a love note to his wife every day before heading to the set of "Law & Order," and he famously donated his corneas after passing away. If that's not the type of person we should be remembering through art, then who is?
Q: So what will this car look like?
A: Simply put... I don't know! Rather than being locked into a design I come up with, I want to rely on the input and creativity of the people who will actually be doing the work. The design will also be determined by budget. The minimum fundraising goal will cover an airbrushed mural of Jerry on the hood, a sparkly new-from-the-ground-up paint job, and some pinstriping flourishes. The more we raise over that minimum, the more intricate the design can become.
I also want to bring backers into the design process, using video updates to document the selection of the car and interview the artists involved.
I know "art car" might conjure images of a Santa Cruz hippie gluing Happy Meal toys all over their VW, but I want to assure you that what I'm going for is something sleek and beautiful, befitting both the art form and the subject. I want to make something as rad as Jerry Orbach.
Q: Hold on, are just trying to use Kickstarter to scam a free car?
A: Nope, I already have a car to get around in. This car will be driven as little as possible--mostly for cruise nights, auto shows, art events, and wherever else an Orbach car may be needed.
Q: Have you done a Kickstarter before?
A: Yes, I drove around the country and painted Sears. With that project, I'd say 50% of the rewards went out right on time, 30 or 40% were mailed within six months of their promised date, and then that last 10% or so were a year or more late (in Kickstarter terms, I'd say that rates a B or B+). Most of the late rewards were late because they involved the creation of individualized works of art. This time, almost all of the rewards are pre-designed and ready to be printed or manufactured pretty much as soon as the Kickstarter closes.
Q: So what are these rewards?
A: I'm glad you asked, because I think they're pretty good! A pledge of $6 will get you your choice of one of these four bumper stickers, and ten dollars gets you all four: 
A $12 donation gets you this nifty suction cup placard:
$15 gets you a handsome laser-cut wood keychain:
$20 gets you this one-of-a-kind air freshener (it smells like roses!):
And $50 gets you the bumper stickers, placard, keychain, and air freshener together in one set.
$125 gets you the bumper stickers, placard, keychain, seven copies of the air freshener (so you'll always have a fresh backup), AND an exclusive T-shirt with this design:
Higher-end rewards start at $200 and include all of the goodies listed above plus things like a simulated ride-along via Skype and your name inscribed on the car itself like they do with donors to museums and such.
If you live in Southern California and have $450 to burn, I'll pick you up in the finished car and we'll go get a burger (again, you must live within 120 miles of Los Angeles to claim this reward, or be traveling there at some point in the near future--I can probably make your Orbach experience fit in with your summer vacation to the Wizarding World of Harry Potter).
Last and not least, $500 will get you... a jacket. Not just any jacket, but an ultra-exclusive, gold satin Jerry Orbach driving jacket, made with some help from my friends at Big Bud Press:
(And because Kickstarter doesn't like you making multiple donations, you can get the jacket and every other thing, plus a tiny piece of original art, for $1000.)
Q: Anything else you'd like to add to get me psyched for this project?
A: Yes:
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The biggest potential headache is that this involves a car, and cars can be giant money-drains, so I hope that I have budgeted appropriately for unexpected expenses. 

The world of "car art" is also a new world for me to navigate, but so far, from talking to car owners and getting quotes from artists, I think that will be fun and interesting rather than challenging.

My previous Kickstarter experience taught me a lot about not overextending myself, and how to get rewards out more efficiently. One of the key things I wish I'd done better with that project was keeping the audience (i.e, you, the backers) more involved in the middle stages, that period between getting funded and completion. That's why I'm planning more video updates, bringing you into the studio (or garage, as it were).
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Anxy will be a bi-annual beautifully-designed magazine about our inner worlds—the personal struggles, the fears that fool us into believing that the rest of the world is normal and we’re not.
Each issue of Anxy will use a central theme to build an original, insightful, and creative perspective through interviews with folks we admire, personal essays, reported features, visual stories, and recommendations for what to read, watch and download to round out the conversation. This won’t be your therapist’s scientific journal. 
This won’t be some self-help manual. And we won’t be telling you how to “fix” an issue.
We feel a real revolution taking place around normalizing mental health outside the medical arena and in the creative space. Anxy will cut through the clutter to offer real discussions and striking explorations of the wildcards our brains and bodies throw our way.
      "Every day millions of seemingly ‘normal people’ suffer in silence. Whether they are hurting in response to tragic events similar to mine, or other equally impactful experiences, these seemingly ‘normal people’ are riddled with so much pain and shame that, like me, they work hard to make sure no one ever notices."
I’m Anxy — But I’m Not the Only One 
Indhira Rojas
“We couldn’t just live with who we were. We needed to create these large personas that masked the tired or anxious or burned out people inside.” 
I’m All Too Familiar with The Sound of Anxy
Jennifer Maerz
“Both addiction and depression thrive on isolation and alienation. They blossom in the depths of loneliness”
Trying to Drink the Anxy Away
Katie MacBride

“Your struggles don’t just go away, but you can choose how you carry the weight.” 
When Anxy Behaviors Get Passed Between Generations 
Michelle Le
See all stories >
Yes, there are great conversations about mental health, depression, anxiety, self-care, basically all the themes we care deeply about, on the Internet. But the truth is they fly by at such a rapid rate, and are surrounded by so much digital junk food, we often don’t have time to form thoughts about or responses to what we’re reading.
So in addition to hosting discussions online, we wanted to create a tactile collection of conversations around these important issues that you could really sit with for months at a time.
Plus, we’re all design nerds. We believe in the power of a stunning publication that sits on your bedside table, on a bookshelf, or even in your therapist’s waiting room, for months to come.
  Indhira Rojas is the founder and creative director of Anxy. For over a decade she has worked in the intersection of branding, editorial, and interaction design for publications such as The Bold Italic, Once, Modern Farmer, Atlas Obscura and the platform Medium. She leads her design consultancy in Berkeley, CA under the name Redindhi Studio.
Jennifer Maerz is Anxy’s editor-in-chief. She’s the former editor-in-chief of Gannett’s digital experiment The Bold Italic, a longtime music editor, and she freelances for a number of publications on topics related to culture, tech, and music, including RollingStone.com, Cosmopolitan.com, Salon.com, and the San Francisco Chronicle.
Bobbie Johnson, Anxy’s editor-at-large, is a senior editor at Medium, and the founding editor of Matter, the ASME-winning, Pulitzer-nominated, online magazine. Before that he was previously a reporter and editor at the Guardian, where he covered race riots and cults, interviewed luminaries like Steve Jobs, and helped coin the word ‘podcast.’
Michelle Le, Anxy’s director of photography, is an award-winning editorial photographer and photo editor based in the Bay Area, specializing in investigative reporting and in-depth enterprising stories. She is a former photo editor for Medium and her work has appeared in WIRED, the Wall Street Journal, Newsweek, Bloomberg and the San Francisco Chronicle, among other print and online publications.
Katie MacBride is Anxy’s assistant editor. She’s a freelance writer and essayist whose work has appeared in The Establishment, Cosmopolitan, and The Bold Italic, among other publications.
Madison Kahn, Anxy’s senior editor, is also senior editor at Medium. She was previously a senior editor and managing editor of the ASME-winning, Pulitzer-nominated online magazine, Matter. Before that, she worked on the editorial teams at Outside magazine and Boston magazine.
Kati Krause, Anxy’s contributing editor, is a writer, editor, and maker of magazines. She has lived in Munich, London, Barcelona and now Berlin, where she is the correspondent for Monocle magazine and develops digital storytelling strategies for media companies. Other magazines she created or worked with include Ling, A Mag for all Seasons, Companion, and Matter.
We also count on an inner circle of mental health professionals and advisory board members, including Natalie Harvey, Coley Williams, and Natasha Vianna, who will collaborate with us and help guide the content around specific issues.
We could really use your help to bring this independent publication to life. We’ve been overwhelmed with all the encouraging emails, newsletter signups, Instagram follows, and Facebook likes that we’ve gotten — just through word of mouth. We feel like we’re on to something special here. 
With your help, we hope to make Anxy a sustainable venture. 
This means we’re asking for your assistance in raising the funds necessary for printing the magazine, yes, but we’ve also made a commitment to launch only if we have the money necessary to pay our contributors as well. So you’re also funding the community around us that’s yearning for a voice. 
In order to really be onto something, we need the financial backing necessary to print and distribute the magazine as well as to pay our contributors. 
We’ll take whatever you can afford to drop in our digital bucket, from $15 (which will earn you a collection of colorful postcards printed with Anxy-approved quotations) to copies of the magazine, invites to an upcoming Anxy private event, and beyond.
——
**NEW REWARD** 
The Tasty Patron
Just added! Limited run of chef's tasting meal at legendary restaurant Chez TJ in Mountain View, California.
  —
Questions? 
Wanna contribute to the magazine when it launches? Leave a comment here or email us at hello@anxymag.com. For updates on the project, you can connect via our Facebook page or join the mailing list on our website. 
You can also follow us on Twitter and Instagram.
—
Video Credits
Director & Editor: Ashley Rodholm
Creative Director: Indhira Rojas 
Executive Producers: Malcolm Pullinger & Mohammad Gorjestani
Producers: Ashley Rodholm & Michelle Le 
Director of Photography: Joe Picard
Assistant Director: Emily Ward
1st Assistant Camera: Dakota Wilder
Gaffer: Alex Herter
Grip: Patrick Walsh
Swing: Casey O'Reiley 
PA: Katie MacBride 
Motion Design: Jason Kerr  
Studio Location: French Press Films
Sound Design & Mix: Joel Raabe
Special Thanks:
Even/Odd 
French Press Films 
Little Giant Lighting 
And all the cast members (you know who you are!)
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
As with any brand new media endeavor, things could potentially go awry—even though we’re trying our hardest to make this thing real. But there are minimal risks when it comes to production. Issues could be delayed, for example, if we face unforeseen manufacturing hiccups (such as the paper supply not arriving on time, or our printer can’t meet our desired production schedule). That being said, we’ve done a lot of research on our vendors and are feeling confident about them.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

For people who are supposed to be good with words, it’s tough for us to figure out what to say about this level of Superb Generosity. Of course, you’ll receive all of our rewards, including a lifetime subscription to Anxy and a lifetime reservation at all future Anxy events. The real reward, however, will be knowing you are a part of bringing something to life that has the potential to help so many people. Thank you, thank you.
INCLUDES:
Inaugural Anxy Magazine Issue
Your name in the magazine as an official patron
The Battery SF Event Guest (Oct 13th)
‘GMUNK Mathographics’ Poster
Anxy Totebag
Anxy Pin
Anxy Postcard Series
Thank You Card

Tickets will only be available for members of The Battery and through this reward, so if you want to attend this incredible night, pledge for it here.

updates.update_userinfo: Less than 24 hours to go for Anxy No. 3!
100%—and going strong! Our stretch goal: The Anxy Podcast
updates.update_content:
WOO HOO!! The Boundaries Issue is officially funded! And to celebrate, we’re announcing an extra special stretch goal...
You’ve brought us so far, so fast. We’re grateful for the overwhelming support you’ve shown once again. This may be our third Kickstarter, but it doesn’t make running a campaign any less nerve wracking. Your encouragement gets us through each day—and with your support, we’re reaching new milestones.
Let’s use the last few days to make another dream come true.
Our $35K Stretch Goal: The Anxy Podcast

We made it past the halfway point—in just over one week.
For those of you who supported us once again, thank you for your continued support. If you haven't checked out our third campaign yet, you can do so here.

Dear Anxy Fans,
YOU are amazing: You’ve been with Anxy from the start. You backed our very first Kickstarter campaign, you know our story, you’ve read our magazine—you might even be repping an Anxy tote (or three). Thank you, from the bottom of our hearts, for being an original fan.
Over the past few months, we've been hard at work on our third issue. We’ve read some incredible stories, collaborated with an amazing team of writers, journalists, photographers and artists, and designed another beautiful magazine that brings it all together.

updates.update_userinfo: Less than 24 hours to go for Anxy No.2!
updates.update_content:
We made it! We passed our fundraising target for issue 2 of Anxy Magazine last night—all thanks to the backing of our readers and supporters.
But we're not done yet.
There are still a few hours left to generate more support for our campaign for our next issue.

updates.update_userinfo: Less than two weeks to go for Anxy No.2!
updates.update_content:
Thanks to everyone who has re-committed to Anxy for our second issue—we've now passed 40% funding! But less than two weeks remain, and the deadline is going to come up on us fast. 
Maybe you're waiting until the last minute to decide. Perhaps you're already a subscriber, or you've found other ways to commit to Anxy or show your support. Even so, there are still ways to help by pledging to our Issue 2 Kickstarter campaign. Here are a few:

updates.update_userinfo: Anxy No.2 is now live on Kickstarter!
updates.update_content:
A year ago we ran our launch campaign for Anxy—and with your help, we were able to turn an idea into reality. We were truly overcome by the massive response, and your kindness helped us deliver an inaugural issue that we could be really proud of.
That work hasn’t gone unnoticed: We’ve seen coverage in the New York Times, San Francisco Chronicle, and a host of international publications; We just got nominated for Launch of the Year in the Stack awards, which are focused on celebrating the best independent magazines. We’ve started distributing in Barnes & Noble stores, as well as through a growing network of independent stockists, and we're steadily building our subscriber base. .

updates.update_userinfo: One year on: You made it happen
updates.update_content:
Dear Anxy people,
There’s so much to tell you! We spent the past few months processing all the lovely feedback we’ve received and making sure we’re delivering on our promises. So, first, thank you for saying hi, appreciating the magazine, and continuing to be a part of the Anxy community—wherever you are.
Here’s a recap of what we’ve done with all that positivity

campaign.story:
Welcome to Erotic Review's Kickstarter page for their 21st anniversary edition: ER21!
We are raising £23,750 and are offering – for four weeks only – exclusive editions of this beautiful book; Not just a great addition to your library (or bedside table) but ER21 will make  the perfect gift for lovers on Valentine's Day!
Our exquisite Library Edition
  History of the Erotic Review
In1994 ER Books (then The Erotic Print Society) was born, publishing limited-edition prints, soon abandoning prints in favour of books. The next year, 1995, Jamie Maclean started up a quarterly newsletter, the Erotic Review, later handing over the editorship to Rowan Pelling, who went on to create a monthly magazine with a 30,000 circulation. 
The Erotic Review, issue 30, Reward N0. 9 Limited edition of cover artwork, signed by the artist, Sylvie Jones, after Francois Boucher and Tracey Emin
  The Erotic Review, issue 21, Reward No. 9, limited edition print of cover artwork, signed by the artist, Sylvie Jones, after Edward Hopper.
A long list of contributors over the years has included Stephen Bayley, Alain de Botton, Kate Copstick, Nick Curtis, Ian Dunt, AC Grayling, Jonathon Green, Barry Humphries, Rod Liddle, Murray Lachlan Young, DBC Pierre, Toby Young and Belle de Jour - Dr Brooke Magnanti.
What we are hoping to do:
Limited gold edition, hand numbered, 350
To celebrate our 21st anniversary we want to produce an exquisite book – ER21 – that revisits some of the best articles and images that we’ve ever published. We’d like it to reflect the way Erotic Review has often been regarded: original, diverse and provocative. Our writers and illustrators have looked at sexuality and relationships in a way that is intelligent, witty and often quite subversive.
So the search was on for the person who could employ all of these attributes; someone who could think outside the box, a little anarchic, even, and with brilliant vision – in other words – a damned fine book designer.
We were incredibly lucky to find Ben Freeman of ditto and luckier still that he has embraced our project with such enthusiasm  and enjoyment. Ben is the creative director at Ditto and Future Artefacts, and art directs The Mushpit magazine. He has been involved with independent publishing and subculture since the early 90s. Ben says: “I remember the Erotic Review from my misspent youth, and I’m really grateful for this opportunity to introduce the publication to a new audience and to discover some treasures in their archive”
Ben Freeman
  Ditto covers
  We think it will be a fantastic book: ER21 will be in two printed editions, the Library Edition, limited to 1,500 and the Gold Edition, limited to just 350 copies. Just some of the writers we hope to include will be cultural critic Stephen Bayley; actor and critic, Kate Copstick; editor of Politics.co.uk, Ian Dunt; 'Mr. Slang' lexicographer, Jonathon Green; author and biographer, Lisa Hilton and ER’s most famous 'editrix' Rowan Pelling amongst others. And the following are just some of the artists whose work we will be showcasing: Aubrey Beardsley; Illustrator Michael Faraday; photographer Michael Alan Grapin and Japanese artist Masaya Yoshioka.
For the cover we will be commissioning a tattoo artist to hand draw a unique design.
What will your contribution support?
We need to raise £23,750 which will enable us to publish this work. We want you to be a part of a collaborative approach to making this happen. We are currently a free on-line magazine supported entirely by voluntary contributions from writers and artists. Whilst we are hoping to raise enough funds to produce the anniversary book any additional funds will go towards bringing us back into print. We think Erotic Review has even greater relevance now than when we started it more than two decades ago.
Available Rewards:
Pledge today and you can enjoy one of many rewards on offer (see examples below):
Reward 3 - Pledge £20
Front cover, hand drawn by a tattoo artist

A spread from the book

Reward No. 5 - An erotic lithographic print, limited to an edition of 350 copies, each numbered by hand. (Size: 210x297 mm) by one of the following artists: Franz von Byros, Michael Faraday, Vivant Denon or Jean Dulac; library edition of ER21 and e-book edition - pledge £50 or more
Detail from Jean Dulac's The Bed
  Franz von Bayros
  Detail from Vivant Denon's Beached Phallus
  Michael Faraday
  Detail from Jean Dulac's The Couple

Reward No. 6 - A beautiful, gold on gold limited edition hand numbered, 300, hardback of ER21 - Pledge £50 or more
Limited gold edition, hand numbered, 300
 Reward No. 7  - This year we joined up with publisher Head of Zeus and presenter and critic Mariella Frostrup to create an anthology of erotic short fiction: Desire. Many of our authors feature and the book will be published on October 6, 2016. 2 erotic prints (see artists above) of your choice and library edition of ER21 - pledge £75 or more 
Desire: 100 of Literature's Sexiest Stories. Whether you're looking for love, lust or something in between, this gorgeous anthology is the perfect gift... or bedside companion
 Reward No. 9 – Limited edition print of one of the Erotic Review's magazine cover, signed by the artist (there are several choices and 2 are shown above in the History of ER section) - a hardback copy of Desire, and a limited gold edition, hand numbered, 300, copy of ER21 - Pledge £250 or more
Reward No. 11 - A gold, limited edition, copy of ER21. 1st edition hardback of Desire: 100 of Literature's Sexiest Stories chosen by Mariella Frostrup and the Erotic Review. An erotic lithographic print, limited to an edition of 10 copies, each signed and numbered by the artist, Sylvie Jones. – Pledge £500 or more
Sylvie Jones lithographic print - detail from The Lovers
 Reward No. 12 - A gold edition of ER21; a 1st edition hardback of Desire: 100 of Literature's Sexiest Stories chosen by Mariella Frostrup and the Erotic Review. An original watercolour by Sylvie Jones (2 details are shown but there are 10 available so do contact us to see the rest) - Pledge £750 or more
Detail from Sylvie Jones watercolour
  Detail from Sylvie Jones watercolour
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
There is always an element of risk when undertaking to publish a book of this nature, but we are an experienced team and are wholly confident that we can deliver our book on time and on budget for Valentine's Day 2017.

If for any reason there are setbacks, then we will keep you informed every step of the way.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
At ELSA AND ME, we believe clothing should be made to fit women, not the other way around. Most women know just how hard it is to find affordable clothing that fits well. It’s said that the standard-sizing for most women’s clothes only fits about 15% of women. We think that's a bad deal for consumers and aim to provide made-to-measure clothing that doesn’t break the bank. 
To expand and improve our service for the fall season, ELSA AND ME is working to purchase its largest bulk order of fabric yet and is enlisting the help of its customers and fans through Kickstarter. Having an inventory of material will speed up our production process, shorten the time between ordering and delivery, and keep our prices low.
All ELSA AND ME products are ethically crafted in collaboration with our production partner Panâh in Nairobi, Kenya.
  As part of our collection to consumers, we offer a maasai-inspired necklace and belt. Both accessories pair perfectly with most any ELSA AND ME dress. For a pledge of $95, you can have your choice of belt (available at custom-length) or necklace.
Apart from five solid colors, we're also offering our made-to-measure ELSA AND ME dresses in two unique limited edition prints: a pattern print and a floral print.
  Our corporate package offer is perfect for a group in an office or department. For a $2,500 pledge, along with 13 made-to-measure ELSA AND ME dresses, your organization will receive a visit from our founder, Maja Svensson, who will give an inspirational speech on entrepreneurship.
                     Zoe Smythe, Fashion Designer, Brooklyn, NY
 "She is an excellent seamstress and used to make many of her own, children's and grandchildren's clothes. Granny Sally favored a classic silhouette but has never been afraid to take risks with fabric and print. She came from a time where textiles had value and nothing was wasted. She instilled in me a deep appreciation for materials and I'm honored to have some of her creations in my wardrobe today."
Lauren Jacobs, Design Manager, Brooklyn, NY
"I think of my maternal grandmother as the pioneer of my family because she was the first to come to America. I like to think I get my sense of adventure and desire to explore new places from her."
Sharufa Rashied-Walker, Founder & Designer, Brooklyn, NY
"My style has been influenced by the grace of my grandmother, the stature of my mother, and the elegance of all the women before me who have embodied the spirit of the art of timeless fashion."
Jessica Mumford, Singer & Dancer, NYC/Kampala
 "Milo in mugs and true love in hugs." - Jessica on her Nana and the impact she had with the little things.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
As with most made-to-order products, there are the occasional challenges and problems that can arise without warning. The need for precision mixed with the chance for human error, as well as the subjective nature of customer satisfaction, can lead to issues. But since ELSA AND ME has been producing made-to-measure dresses for over two years, we're confident in our experience to provide well-made products. Additionally, our dedication to quality and our customers, means that should an issues arise, we'll go out of our way to ensure our dresses are the best fit possible and communicate/work with customers to make certain that happens.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
The idea for the product came when our daughter was sick with the flu.   After two trips running into her room hearing that dreaded "hurl" noise, we knew it was going to be a long night.  
 Like so many other parents, we put a metal mixing bowl on her nightstand and said, "If you can't make it into the toilet in time, make sure you don't throw up on your bed or the floor."  Once we heard the cling of the metal on her nightstand we knew we were being called into action again.  After the third trip to her bedroom the idea was born.  
It was clear that the product needed to have several features: 1- It needed to glow in the dark so it would be the first thing people would see when waking up sick, 2- It needed to anchor right next to the bed so it didn't have to be stored too far away from the bed, and 3- It needed to easily collapse and store under the bed when not in use.
  Did your family used to have a dedicated "barf bucket?"  Once someone in the house marked their territory with that bucket (or bowl) no one wanted to use it for anything else.  It just feels wrong to mix a salad where sister Sally deposited the Halloween candy she just gorged on.  What we found was that the more we looked into this idea the more other friends confirmed the product's viability. 
There are several features that friends and family have requested to be incorporated into the product.  Recently we've heard from two separate groups on social media who've said Barf Bucket could be very useful.  The groups were Cyclical Vomiting Syndrome and Hyperemesis Gravidarum (extreme morning sickness).  Both people from these groups tend to use a mixing bowl or a disposable paper or plastic bag.  
We continue to get great feedback even after we've solidified the design. Some of the product suggestions might still be able to be incorporated.  We'll keep them in mind for stretch goals:)
     Be sure to share our project!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
There are certain risks associated with every projected that is just beginning to be manufactured on Kickstarter. Our product is no different. We feel that part of our experience manufacturing overseas and being transparent about timeline and logistics will minimize the risks. 

We're very confident that we'll be able to deliver a quality product and we're 95% certain we'll be able to on time. A lot of projects on Kickstarter see their delivery dates delayed, sometimes by several months. Having gone through the full design/prototype/fulfillment process means that we know what questions to ask and how long we should expect to wait in between refined versions of the product.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Queer Quest is a queer-as-fuck point-and-clit adventure game. Inspired by classic gems like Monkey Island, Kings Quest, and Leisure Suit Larry, but set in a queer community in the pacific northwest. You play as Lupe, a long haired butch with a heart of gold.  She lives with her babely girlfriend, Alexis,  that is until one day when Alexis gets kidnapped! You gotta help Lupe by deciphering clues, talking to lovable weirdos, and navigating self care.
"Queer Quest is another entry into the burgeoning landscape of queer games, and with any luck, others will soon be naming it as their inspiration too." - Kill Screen
"I met the developer of this game at XOXO. I was fascinated and intrigued. Glad to see it's on Kickstarter!" - Ron Gilbert (Monkey Island 1&2, Maniac Mansion)
"Never in our wildest dreams did we think we’d be playing a video game about our actual lives! We’re so ready." - Huffington Post
"Now that I think about it, 'point and clit' is pretty clever." - The Cliqist
    Queer Quest is set in a gayborhood in the Pacific Northwest.  It is a story driven puzzle game that explores the oddballs that shape a community.  There's a wide range of characters, most based on real people in a real community.  
Queer Quest was inspired by a protest that happened a few years ago in Portland, OR.  There was a physical assault on a queer couple, and the organized response was for folks to hold hands across a bridge.  That protest inspired me to make this game.  Queer Quest is about how community responds to tragedy.
       (in order left to right from photo)
Hagen Deloss ... Art
Mo Cohen ... Programming / Writing / Design
Maria Del Castillo ... Music
(Not pictured: Nick Sahoyah who drops by and helps with comedic & puzzle refinement, Emily Madly who did the character concept art, and Vincent Cruz who does the tarot art. "WHAT TAROT ART?" You ask? You'll have to play to find out.)
I'm raising money in order to pay the team a fair wage.  Art, animation and music is all time consuming, and working on a shoe-string budget is rough and slow.  Donating to this Kickstarter will directly help expand the small, yet growing, canon of queer video games.  This is a passion project that I've been scoping for years and finally built enough skills to start developing.  I've been paying for art and music out of pocket, working a full-time day job while developing Queer Quest at night.  And it isn't sustainable, so now I turn to my communities of queers, gamers, and everyone else who needs this game to exist as much as I do.
The bulk of the money will go to paying for art and animation.  Point-and-click adventure games are really graphic heavy and since I'm contributing the programming/writing for free, the next highest cost is the art.  After that, a chunk goes to taxes, fees, music, rewards, marketing, and equipment.  A small percentage ( < .001% ) might also go to flavor blasted cheddar goldfish, because we eat a lot of those.
Pending successful Kickstarter, we plan to launch the game in the next three years, because we want to take the time to do it right. If this Kickstarter fails, this project will take around ten years to complete if I continue to fund out of pocket.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Any indie game company risks running out of money, burn out, over-scoping. Making a game is really fun sometimes and really tedious other times. I document all of the challenges that come up in the dev blog if you're interested in reading how many hats one person can wear at the same time. But I wouldn't worry about my dedication to making this project happen, I've been planning this game for four years now, all the while I've been building up my programming skills, writing plot points and puzzles, and fearing that someone would beat me to making this game first. Making a game is hard, but not making this game is even harder for me.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hi all!
I'll keep this brief: if you haven't checked out our Patreon, now is a great time to.  Just for V-Day, we put out a new demo of Queer Quest (windows and mac).  
Making a game takes a long time, especially when juggling a day job, so I'm really grateful for all the support and patience folks have shown. I wanted to release this demo as a thank you and a little peak into what the game is shaping into.  The demo also has a bonus feature of being able to explore a handful of unfinished scenes in the game, in case you're curious how messy games can look like before they're done.

Hi all! I'll keep this brief because I keep most of my content on Patreon nowadays, but I wanted to send this update to as many folks as I could reach!
When I first started this Kickstarter, the topic of trans women and trans femme representation was brought up quite a bit.  I wrote a blog post about learning how to have good representation of trans women and trans femmes (for folks who aren't), but wasn't able to post it because I was trying to get it on a specific publication I admire.  It's much later than I'd hope for, but that opportunity has officially fallen through so I'm taking this chance to (as well as our ).  I am slowly having more conversations with other folks from minority groups about representation, and plan on writing more about these experiences (next up/currently in progress is a post about representing people with disabilities in games).  Other game dev progress will be posted to the Patreon only, but I will keep this series about representation available to all on .

campaign.story:
Thee Temple ov Psychick Youth has been convened in order to act as a catalyst and focus for the Individual development off all those who wish to reach inwards and strike out. Maybe you are already one of these, already feeling different, dissatisfied, separate from the mass around you, instinctive and alert? You are already one of us. The fact that you have this message is a start in itself.
Conceived in the aftermath of the punk and industrial countercultures, Thee Temple ov Psychick Youth (TOPY) was an "anti-cult" that drew on the tenets of provocation, transgression, and the DIY ethos to form an internationally reaching network bound together by an esoteric sensibility. 
With experimental pop group Psychic TV serving as the public's access to Temple doctrine (shattering a Guinness World Record for musical output in the process), the decade long spiritual, intellectual, and sexual revolution that TOPY would instigate, for tens of thousands of members worldwide, represented an unprecedented model for radical communion. 
TOPY strove to transcend the normative constructs of culture, sexuality, order, and reason, examine and undermine systems of power, and reach ecstatic states of being. In doing so its members often hurdled past the outer limits of propriety, arousing the moral wrath of “Satanic Panic” era British authorities and causing the subsequent Scotland Yard raid and political exile of the group’s central figurehead, artist and provocateur Genesis P-Orridge.
A MESSAGE FROM THE TEMPLE is the first official documentary about Thee Temple Of Psychick Youth (years 1981-1991), tracing its influences and inception to its dramatic downfall and enduring legacy. 
Told with unprecedented access through the eyes of its members, collaborators, and persecutors via contemporary interviews, personal archives, and historical accounts from the mainstream media, A MESSAGE FROM THE TEMPLE will provide an intimate portrait of the artists, occultists, and rock stars that surrounded Thee Temple Ov Psychick Youth.
It is our belief as filmmakers that stories such as this must be told if human history is to survive, progress, or have any meaning whatsoever.
  A MESSAGE FROM THE TEMPLE isn't just a film, it's a call to arms. We seek Individuals to preserve the Temple that resides within us all.
If you are attracted in any way by what we have already said we suggest the following action. 
WE ARE NOW ACCEPTING DONATIONS
We need initial seed money to not only make this project possible, but to tell this story without compromise. 
Our initial goal represents a quarter of what we need to make this project, but it will get us started. Any additional funds will go towards our complete budget of $200,000, which includes post production and finishing costs for the film. Should this occur, a variety of new and exclusive rewards will be offered. You hold Thee Key.
Our initial costs are as follows: 
PRODUCTION This includes the purchase and rental of equipment, and any other fees incurred during the production.
TRAVEL A large portion of our production costs relate to international travel for interviews and archival research, with trips to the UK, Europe, and across the US. Costs include flights, accommodations, car rentals and gas for our team. 
PRESERVATION & RESTORATION The vast archive of films, videocassettes, audio cassettes, photographs, and original documents that require high quality digital transfers, preservation, and in some cases, costly restoration fees. 
LICENSING AND RIGHTS USAGE for the archival music & footage used in the film, and the ability to distribute the final product across all relevant platforms upon its release. 
COMPENSATION The hiring of an editor to manage the vast archival material and contemporary interviews generated from this project. 
SHARE OUR CAMPAIGN 
WE ARE NOT SEEKING FOLLOWERS
WE ARE SEEKING COLLABORATORS 
facebook.com/amessagefromthetemple 
instagram.com/amessagefromthetemple
twitter.com/uncleanpictures
www.amessagefromthetemple.com 
SHARE YOUR STORIES AND YOUR TALENTS 
If you are unable to contribute financially to our campaign, we seek your help otherwise. 
Have you... ever participated or been involved in Thee Temple ov Psychick Youth or know those who have?

Do you... collect media related to Thee Temple ov Psychick Youth or Psychic TV you would be willing to share? 

Do... you have interest in taking action? We need individuals willing to volunteer their time for the management and organization of archival. 
WRITE TO US AT THIS ADDRESS
join@amessagefromthetemple.com 
  Thee Temple is committed to building a modern network. And this network is inevitably faced with thee task ov action to communicate survival and social evolution to others.
GENESIS BREYER P-ORRIDGE
Genesis Breyer P-Orridge is an English singer-songwriter, musician, poet, performance and visual artist, and occultist. After rising to notability as the founder of the COUM Transmissions artistic collective and then fronting the industrial band Throbbing Gristle, P-Orridge was a founding member of Thee Temple ov Psychick Youth occult group, and fronted the experimental band Psychic TV. Through h/er current “breaking sex” artworks, P-Orridge identifies as pandrogyne, a formed third gender with h/er partner Ladye Jaye Breyer P-Orridge. P-Orridge’s remarkable body of underground work reminds us that when you believe in something, artistic integrity demands that you live by it too.
CURRENT & FUTURE INDIVIDUALS
We have already conducted interviews with Carl Abrahamsson (TOPY Scan, Edda Publishing), Paul "Bee" Hampshire (PTV, Getting The Fear, Into A Circle), V. Vale (RE/Search Publications, Search & Destroy), John Aes-Nihil (The Archives of Aesthetic Nihilism), Jason Louv (editor of Thee Psychick Bible, founder of Ultraculture, Occultist), J.G. Thirlwell (Foetus), Don Bolles (The Germs, 45 Grave, Nervous Gender), and Scott Treleaven (The Salivation Army).
We have confirmed upcoming interviews with Alaura O'Dell (previously Paula P-Orridge, PTV, TOPY, ex-wife of Genesis and mother of their two children), Douglas Rushkoff (author and media theorist), Richard Metzger (Disinformation, Dangerous Minds), Tom Headbanger (head of TOPY North America), Rose McDowall (Strawberry Switchblade, Current 93), Drew McDowall (PTV, Coil), William Breeze (Coil, PTV, current head of the O.T.O.), and David Keenan (England's Hidden Reverse, The Wire). More confirmations to be announced soon. 
REPORTS OF OUR ACTIVITIES
Read an interview with the filmmakers in CLRVYNT, and one with director Jacqueline Castel in Hero Magazine. Listen to a playlist of essential TOPY cuts curated by our producer and co-owner of Dais Records Ryan Martin in Self-Titled.
Other reports: Billboard, Bullett, Citizen LA, CLRVYNT, Crack Magazine, The Creators Project, CVLT Nation, Dangerous Minds, Dazed, i-D, Impose, MXDWN, Pitchfork, The Quietus, Screen Anarchy, The Ransom Note, Spin, Tribe Media, The Wire.
    We present to you artifacts from the original Temple Mail Order.
NEW EXCLUSIVE REWARDS AVAILABLE OCTOBER 23RD 23:00 
COIL "SUMMER SOLSTICE: BEE STINGS" 7"
Signed by John Balance, Peter "Sleazy" Christopherson, Drew McDowall, and Bill Breeze. Green Vinyl originally limited to 50 copies. By generous donation from the personal collection of Drew McDowall, limited to 1 copy, available for 23 hours only. 
DREW MCDOWALL "COLLAPSE" TEST PRESSING LP
Test Pressing of Drew McDowall's "Collapse" LP on Dais Records, signed by the artist. Limited to 1 copy.
WILLIAM S. BURROUGHS ART EDITION LP OF "NOTHING HERE NOW BUT THE RECORDINGS" 
Art Edition of William S. Burroughs' "Nothing Here Now but the Recordings" LP reissued on Dais Records. Limited to an edition of 23, with artwork donated by Jes Aurelius of Ascetic House. 
WILLIAM S. BURROUGHS ART EDITION POSTER
18" x 24" Silk Screened Poster for "Nothing Here Now But The Recordings" William S. Burroughs LP reissued on Dais Records. Designed by Jes Aurelius in an edition of 23.
 GP-O by JPT INTERVIEW CASSETTE
Previously unreleased Genesis P-Orridge interview on TOPY, conducted by Jean-Pierre Turmel of Sordide Sentimental on March 10th 1984 in Rouen, France. Newly dubbed tapes with original, dead stock silk screened TOPY cassette covers. C46 Cassette, limited edition of 40.
BLEACH DYED SLEEVELESS PSYCHIC CROSS TANK 
Reproduction of the original sleeveless black tank with gold Psychic Cross, bleach dyed and limited to an edition of 23. As modeled by former TOPY member Paul "Bee" Hampshire. 
 PSYCHIC HEARTS SHIRT 
The below shirt, designed by our friends at Psychic Hearts for our NYC fundraising benefit, is now available in limited sizing exclusive to our campaign backers. Limited to an edition of 50 on white t-shirts. Reads: "Abolish Fear, Establish Trust."
Campaign Exclusive. 
TELEVISION MAGICK 
An exact replication of the Television Magick booklet, originally published in 1988. The first attempt to systematically explore the practical and theoretical implications of Television Magick.
MODERN PRIMITIVES FROM RE/SEARCH PUBLICATIONS 
5 copies of the hardbound copy of the Modern Primitives book published by RE/Search Publications, from the original edition of 500, signed by V. Vale. Featuring Genesis & Paula P-Orridge. 
PROPAGANDA
A PERSONAL MESSAGE FROM THE TEMPLE OV PSYCHICK YOUTH
The original introductory leaflet.
PSYCHIC TELEVISION TRANSMISSIONS
These are video-cassettes intended for instruction of Psychick Youth. They are celebrations of experience, provocations of thought, image, sound and Spirit, integrated as information and not as entertainment. Psychic TV is not intended to be a replacement for conventional programming, but rather the first step towards a de-programming.
THEE GREY BOOK
Thee original and essential statements ov Thee Temple Ov Psychick Youth. No Individual can begin to understand TOPY without it.
THEE PSYCHICK BIBLE 
The most profound new manual on practical magick—taking from its Crowleyan level of liberation and empowerment of the individual to a next level of realization that magick must then give back to its environment and community. Paperback copies signed by Genesis Breyer P-Orridge. 
INSIGNIA
The most instantly effective strategy for generating very quickly the impression of a serious, focused, militant network. 
THEE GREY SHIRT, SWEATSHIRT, & POLO 
Grey because it lies between black and white as nothing is certain, everything permitted. 
THEE BADGES 
THEE PATCH AND THEE KEY
THEE STICKERS AND THEE TOTE 
RITUAL CUTTINGS IN NYC, LA, & LONDON
The TOPY haircut is a combination of the sensuous in the form of a long tail of hair at the back of the head, with the rest of the head shaved in reference to the ascetic spiritual disciplines.
To be conducted with Genesis Breyer P-Orridge's original clippers by the filmmaking team. Available at participating record stores Material World (ex-Heaven Street) in NYC and Mount Analog in Los Angeles and participating cinema Close Up Film Centre in London (in tandem with a satellite screening of our NYC RITUAL CUTTINGS event, TBA soon). 
GENESIS BREYER P-ORRIDGE SIGIL ARTWORK
Reproduction of original sigil artwork by Genesis Breyer P-Orridge from 1987, as featured in the short film MOONCHILD. Limited to an edition of 23 and signed by the artist. 
BULLET CHARMS & NECKLACE
As part of the ongoing discussions between the ratios within Thee Temple regarding the sigil process, these charms were sent out as an acknowledgement and thank you for your sigil participation. Each charm or necklace will include a Certificate of Authenticity signed by Genesis Breyer P-Orridge.
EXCLUSIVE NYC INVITATION TO THEE TEMPORARY TEMPLE
Thank you for joining us at Thee Temporary Temple on Saturday, October 15th for a one night only benefit event at a historic church in NYC attended by hundreds of people. We screened rare TOPY archival, followed by a discussion with Genesis Breyer P-Orridge (TOPY UK), Tom Headbanger (Coyote 2/12, TOPY North America), Caleigh Fisher (TOPY Toronto), Paul "Bee" Hampshire (TOPY UK), & Pieter Schoolwerth (TOPY North America).  
 You can view photographs from the event here. 
  JACQUELINE CASTEL, DIRECTOR & CINEMATOGRAPHER
Jacqueline Castel is a NYC & LA based filmmaker, archivist, curator and longtime collaborator with Sacred Bones Records. Her work has premiered at Sundance, SXSW, BAMcinemaFest, and festivals worldwide, and has featured collaborations with filmmakers Jim Jarmusch and John Carpenter. Jacqueline’s archival and curatorial experience has extended to the estate of H.R. Giger, the Genesis Breyer P-Orridge archives at the Tate Britain, and screenings of the work of David Lynch. She has interviewed dozens of creative luminaries, including filmmaker Errol Morris on serial killers, musician Cherie Currie on UFOs and telekinesis, and artist Joe Coleman on his personal collection at the Odditorium. She is directing her first narrative feature film in Tokyo in 2017.
www.jacquelinecastel.com 
RYAN MARTIN, PRODUCER
Ryan Martin is a musician and artist currently residing in Brooklyn, NY who co-founded Dais Records in 2007 and avant-garde label Robert & Leopold in 2010. He has taken part in hundreds of performances over the past two decades and has worked with dozens of leading experimental underground artists such as Genesis Breyer P-Orridge and Maurizio Bianchi. Ryan has also managed Genesis Breyer P-Orridge since 2008, a relationship that started in 2004 when he was taken on board to help catalog P-Orridge's archives.
www.daisrecords.com 
CALEB BRAATEN, PRODUCER
Caleb Braaten owns and operates Sacred Bones, a NYC-based label with a focus on forward-thinking contemporary music, art, books, and film. In addition to releasing dozens of new independent artists' output, Sacred Bones has teamed with cult auteurs David Lynch, Jim Jarmusch, and John Carpenter to release their musical work.
www.sacredbonesrecords.com 
ALDONA WATTS, PRODUCER
Aldona Watts is a filmmaker working in the Bay Area and New York. Her directorial debut, award-winning feature documentary LAND OF SONGS (2015), premiered with the Margaret Mead film Festival at the American Museum of Natural History in New York and is screening at festivals internationally. Aldona is also an organizer at Her Girl Friday, a Brooklyn collective of women nonfiction storytellers. She has produced audio documentaries on topics involving gender, music, and culture.
www.landofsongs.com
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
A MESSAGE FROM THE TEMPLE is a reality that we will manifest. It will not be easy. Any project of this scale requires commitment if it is to succeed. 

Gaining the trust of the Individuals in this story is important to our team, requiring time and patience, and interviews require extensive logistical planning internationally. These perspectives, if not accessed now, risk being lost forever if we do not begin this process now. 

The TOPY archives are scattered across the globe in various formats and states of erosion that will take care to source, log, and restore properly. 

Lastly, creating a final film that our team believes in morally, spiritually, and aesthetically takes time, consideration, and care. 

There are challenges ahead, and we accept responsibility. Gladly and with excitement and deliberate ignorance of the outcome. We revel in mystery and surprise. We bury ourselves in challenges and dreams. We embrace all possibilities and impossibilities with joy and excitement.

Our Aim is Wakefulness. Our Enemy is Dreamless Sleep.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter
